entry.content:
NC1âŠ†L/polyâŠ†NL/polyâŠ†AC1NC^1\subseteq L/poly\subseteq NL/poly\subseteq AC^1NC1âŠ†L/polyâŠ†NL/polyâŠ†AC1.

The model of branching programs that give a precise characterization of L/polyL/polyL/poly and NL/polyNL/polyNL/poly.

Deterministic / non-deterministic branching program

Boolean Branching Program

Deterministic

ğŸ“–Definition 32. A Deterministic Boolean branching program BBB with nnn inputs consists of the following:

  • A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A), where the out-degree of all nodes is in {0,1,2}\{0,1,2\}{0,1,2}.
  • A partial labeling â„“V:Vâ†’{0,1,x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\ell_V:V\to\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}â„“Vâ€‹:Vâ†’{0,1,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹} of the nodes of DDD.
  • A partial labeling â„“A:Aâ†’{0,1}\ell_A:A\to\{0,1\}â„“Aâ€‹:Aâ†’{0,1} of the edges of DDD.
  • An initial node sâˆˆVs\in VsâˆˆV.

When node vvv is not labeled by â„“V\ell_Vâ„“Vâ€‹, we say that vvv is dummy.

If â„“V(v)âˆˆ{0,1}\ell_V(v)\in\{0,1\}â„“Vâ€‹(v)âˆˆ{0,1}, we say that vvv is an output node.

The graph DDD and the labeling function â„“V,â„“A\ell_V,\ell_Aâ„“Vâ€‹,â„“Aâ€‹ should satisfy:

  1. The node sss is not a dummy node.
  2. If â„“V(v)âˆˆ{x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\ell_V(v)\in\{x_1,\cdots,x_n\}â„“Vâ€‹(v)âˆˆ{x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹}, the out-degree of vvv is 222, and one outgoing edges of vvv is labeled 000 and 111 by â„“A\ell_Aâ„“Aâ€‹ respectively.
  3. If â„“V(v)âˆˆ{0,1}\ell_V(v)\in\{0,1\}â„“Vâ€‹(v)âˆˆ{0,1}, i.e., vvv is an output node, the out-degree of vvv is 000.
  4. If vvv is a dummy node, the in-degree of vvv is not 000, the out-degree of vvv is 111.

A branching program with nnn inputs compute a Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1} in a natural way.

Given an input xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n, start in the initial node sss, follow a path to an output node, thereby giving the value of f(x)f(x)f(x).

When passing through dummy node, directly go through the unique path.

When passing through labeled node, go to 111-labeled edge if xi=1x_i=1xiâ€‹=1, 000-labeled edge if xi=0x_i=0xiâ€‹=0.

Non-deterministic

Simply modify the deterministic branching program:

  • label of vertices is â„“V:Vâ†’{0,1,âˆ—,x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\ell_V:V\to\{0,1,*,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}â„“Vâ€‹:Vâ†’{0,1,âˆ—,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹}. If â„“V(v)=âˆ—\ell_V(v)=*â„“Vâ€‹(v)=âˆ—, vvv is called a choice node.
  • We require the out-degree of vvv is 222 and outgoing edges are not labeled by â„“A\ell_Aâ„“Aâ€‹.

For a given input xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n, traverse the branching program from sss, but at a choice node choose to follow an arbitrary arc.

We say that the non-deterministic branching program accepts xxx if there exist such choices leading the path to an output node labeled 111.

ğŸ“–Definition 33. The size of a branching program is the number of nodes in the branching program. The length of a branching program is the length of the longest path from sss to a node to out degree 000.

Then define complexity classes of languages computed by size-bounded branching programs.

ğŸ“–Definition 34. Let S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N\to\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N. BPSIZE(S(n))BPSIZE(S(n))BPSIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of deterministic Boolean branching program of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)). Similarly, NPBSIZE(S(n))NPBSIZE(S(n))NPBSIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of non-deterministic Boolean branching program of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)).

ğŸ¤”Theorem 43. L/poly=BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(nO(1))L/poly=BPSIZE(n^{O(1)}),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(n^{O(1)})L/poly=BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(nO(1)).

ğŸ¤”Theorem 44. L=ULâˆ’BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL=ULâˆ’NBPSIZE(nO(1))L=U_L-BPSIZE(n^{O(1)}),NL=U_L-NBPSIZE(n^{O(1)})L=ULâ€‹âˆ’BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL=ULâ€‹âˆ’NBPSIZE(nO(1)).

Programs over Monoids and Bounded Width Branching Programs

monoid å«å¹ºåŠç¾¤

What if we restrict the width of branching programs?

Consider the width to be constant.

ğŸ“–Definition 35. A branching program BBB is in layered form, if there is a partition of the nodes of BBB into layers V1,â‹¯â€‰,Vl,V=V1âˆªâ‹¯âˆªVlV_1,\cdots ,V_l,V=V_1\cup\cdots\cup V_lV1â€‹,â‹¯,Vlâ€‹,V=V1â€‹âˆªâ‹¯âˆªVlâ€‹, in such a way that every edge go between some pair of adjacent layers ViV_iViâ€‹ and Vi+1V_{i+1}Vi+1â€‹.

ğŸ“–Definition 36. The width of a branching program with partition into layers V=V1âˆªâ‹¯âˆªVlV=V_1\cup\cdots\cup V_lV=V1â€‹âˆªâ‹¯âˆªVlâ€‹ is the size of the largest layer, maxiâˆ£Viâˆ£max_i|V_i|maxiâ€‹âˆ£Viâ€‹âˆ£.

Then here comes new complexity classes.

ğŸ“–Definition 37. BWBPBWBPBWBP is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean branching programs polynomial size and width O(1)O(1)O(1).

Itâ€™s easy to show AC0âŠ†BWBPAC^0\subseteq BWBPAC0âŠ†BWBP (â“)

Conjecture: MAJâˆˆÌ¸BWBPMAJ\not\in BWBPMAJî€ âˆˆBWBP.

Fact: BWBP=NC1BWBP=NC^1BWBP=NC1.

Consider computation over finite algebraic structures, finite groups.

ğŸ“–Definition 38. A monoid is a set MMM closed under an associative binary operation s.t. MMM has an identity element:

  1. For all x,yâˆˆMx,y\in Mx,yâˆˆM, we have xyâˆˆMxy\in MxyâˆˆM. å°é—­æ€§
  2. For all x,y,zâˆˆMx,y,z\in Mx,y,zâˆˆM, we have x(yz)=(xy)zx(yz)=(xy)zx(yz)=(xy)z. ç»“åˆå¾‹
  3. There is an element 1âˆˆM1\in M1âˆˆM s.t. 1x=x1=x1x=x1=x1x=x1=x for all xâˆˆMx\in MxâˆˆM å«æœ‰å¹ºå…ƒ

The set of functions from a set SSS to itself which forms a monoid, denoted TST_STSâ€‹.

The set of partial functions from a set SSS to itself forms a monoid, denote PTSPT_SPTSâ€‹.

Commonsense: Any group is a monoid.

ğŸ“–Definition 39. Let MMM be a finite monoid. A program PPP over MMM with nnn inputs consists of the following:

  1. A sequence I1,â‹¯â€‰,IlI_1,\cdots,I_lI1â€‹,â‹¯,Ilâ€‹ of triples of the form âŸ¨i,g0,g1âŸ©\langle i,g_0,g_1\rangleâŸ¨i,g0â€‹,g1â€‹âŸ©, where iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯â€‰,n}i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,n} and g0,g1âˆˆMg_0,g_1\in Mg0â€‹,g1â€‹âˆˆM.
  2. An accepting set AâŠ†MA\subseteq MAâŠ†M.

The triples is called instructions of the program PPP.

A program PPP over MMM with nnn inputs define a Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1} in a natural way:

  • Let xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n.
  • The output of an instruction I=âŸ¨i,g0,g1âŸ©I=\langle i,g_0,g_1\rangleI=âŸ¨i,g0â€‹,g1â€‹âŸ© is given by I(x)=gxiI(x)=g_{x_i}I(x)=gxiâ€‹â€‹.
  • The output of the program is P(x)=âˆj=1lIj(x)P(x)=\prod_{j=1}^lI_j(x)P(x)=âˆj=1lâ€‹Ijâ€‹(x).
  • Finally f(x)=1f(x)=1f(x)=1 iff P(x)âˆˆAP(x)\in AP(x)âˆˆA.

ğŸ“–Definition 40. The length of a program PPP is the number of instructions of PPP.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 10: Let fff be a Boolean function computed by a family of polynomial length programs over a finite monoid MMM. Then fâˆˆNC1f\in NC^1fâˆˆNC1.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 11. BWBPâŠ†NC1BWBP\subseteq NC^1BWBPâŠ†NC1.

Barringtonâ€™s Theorem

Any language in NC1NC^1NC1 can be computed by polynomial size constant width branching programs.

Theorem 45 (Barringtonâ€™s Theorem). BWBP=NC1BWBP=NC^1BWBP=NC1.

By constructing polynomial length programs over group S5S_5S5â€‹ of permutations of 555 elements.

The width is fixed 555.

We denote the identity permutation by eâˆˆS5e\in S_5eâˆˆS5â€‹.

ğŸ“–Definition 41. Let PPP be a program over S5S_5S5â€‹ and let ÏƒâˆˆS5\sigma\in S_5ÏƒâˆˆS5â€‹ be a 555-cycle. We say that PPP Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ-computes a Boolean function fff if P(x)=ÏƒP(x)=\sigmaP(x)=Ïƒ when f(x)=1f(x)=1f(x)=1 and P(x)=eP(x)=eP(x)=e when f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0. We can also simply say that PPP 555-cycle computes fff.

ğŸ¤”Lemma. Let Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ and Ï„\tauÏ„ be 555-cycles. If a program PPP over S5S_5S5â€‹ of length lll Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ-computes fff, then there is another program Pâ€²P'Pâ€² of length lll over S5S_5S5â€‹ that Ï„\tauÏ„-computes fff.

ğŸ¤”Lemma. If a program PPP over S5S_5S5â€‹ of length lll 555-cycle computes fff, then there is another program Pâ€²P'Pâ€² of length lll that 555-cycle computes Â¬f\neg fÂ¬f.

ğŸ“–Definition 42 (commutator äº¤æ¢å­). Let GGG be a group and g,hâˆˆGg,h\in Gg,hâˆˆG. The commutator [g,h][g,h][g,h] is the element gâˆ’1hâˆ’1ghg^{-1}h^{-1}ghgâˆ’1hâˆ’1gh.

ğŸ¤”Lemma. There exists 555-cycles Ïƒ1\sigma_1Ïƒ1â€‹ and Ïƒ2\sigma_2Ïƒ2â€‹ s.t. their commutator [Ïƒ1,Ïƒ2][\sigma_1,\sigma_2][Ïƒ1â€‹,Ïƒ2â€‹], is also a 555-cycle.

Ïƒ1=(1,2,3,4,5),Ïƒ2=(1,3,5,4,2).\sigma_1=(1,2,3,4,5),\sigma_2=(1,3,5,4,2).Ïƒ1â€‹=(1,2,3,4,5),Ïƒ2â€‹=(1,3,5,4,2).

[Ïƒ1,Ïƒ2]=(1,2,5,3,4)[\sigma_1,\sigma_2]=(1,2,5,3,4)[Ïƒ1â€‹,Ïƒ2â€‹]=(1,2,5,3,4)

ğŸ¤”Proposition 12. Let CCC be a fanin 222 circuit of depth ddd. Then there exist a program PPP of length at most 4d4^d4d that 555-cycle computes the output of CCC.

By Proposition 11 and 12, we obtain Barringtonâ€™s Theorem.
entry.summary: NC

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 1 Core-Stability Federated Learning
entry.content:
I will begin a new project work 24 Fall: FAIRNESS IN AI/ML THROUGH THE LENS OF SOCIAL CHOICE

The basic outline is following Tutorial: Fairness in AI/ML via Social Choice by Evi Micha & Nisarg Shah in EC 2024.

The first paper I have read in last semester, Fairness in Federated Learning via Core-Stability, which was one of the possible topics.

Brief notes is here.

âš ï¸We found that the basis of this paper may make no sense!!!

I will try to understand some mathematical proof in this semester.

Core-Stability

Revisit the definition of Core-Stability: A predictor Î¸âˆˆP\theta\in PÎ¸âˆˆP is called core stable if there exist no other Î¸â€²âˆˆP\theta'\in PÎ¸â€²âˆˆP and no subset SSS of agents, s.t. âˆ£Sâˆ£nui(Î¸â€²)â‰¥ui(Î¸)\frac{|S|}{n}u_i(\theta')\ge u_i(\theta)nâˆ£Sâˆ£â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â‰¥uiâ€‹(Î¸) for all iâˆˆSi\in SiâˆˆS, with at least one strict inequality.

âš ï¸âš ï¸âš ï¸What is WRONG with the claim

Setting S=[n]S=[n]S=[n] in definition, there is no predictor Î¸â€²âˆˆP\theta'\in PÎ¸â€²âˆˆP where âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)>n\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\gt nâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹>n.

The problem is, according to the definition, when we plug in S=[n]S=[n]S=[n], there exist no Î¸â€²âˆˆP\theta'\in PÎ¸â€²âˆˆP s.t.

ui(Î¸â€²)â‰¥ui(Î¸)âˆ€iâˆˆSâ‡”ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)â‰¥1âˆ€iâˆˆSu_i(\theta')\ge u_i(\theta)\forall i\in S\\\Lrarr\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\ge 1\forall i\in Suiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â‰¥uiâ€‹(Î¸)âˆ€iâˆˆSâ‡”uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹â‰¥1âˆ€iâˆˆS

with at least one strict inequality.

But can it be directly sum up? âˆ‘iui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸)â‰¥n\sum_i\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\ge nâˆ‘iâ€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹â‰¥n???

A counter example is here:

Assume Î¸\thetaÎ¸ is core-stable and n=3n=3n=3,

u1(Î¸)=10,u2(Î¸)=11,u3(Î¸)=12u_1(\theta)=10,u_2(\theta)=11,u_3(\theta)=12u1â€‹(Î¸)=10,u2â€‹(Î¸)=11,u3â€‹(Î¸)=12

According to the definition, there exist no Î¸â€²âˆˆP\theta'\in PÎ¸â€²âˆˆP (We plug in S=[3]S=[3]S=[3]) s.t.

u1(Î¸â€²)â‰¥10,u2(Î¸â€²)â‰¥11,u3(Î¸â€²)â‰¥12u_1(\theta')\ge10,u_2(\theta')\ge11,u_3(\theta')\ge12u1â€‹(Î¸â€²)â‰¥10,u2â€‹(Î¸â€²)â‰¥11,u3â€‹(Î¸â€²)â‰¥12

with at least one strict inequality.

But according to definition, there may exist Î¸â€²âˆˆP\theta'\in PÎ¸â€²âˆˆP s.t.

u1(Î¸â€²)=9.9<10,u2(Î¸â€²)=10000â‰¥11,u3(Î¸â€²)=10000â‰¥12,u_1(\theta')=9.9\lt10,u_2(\theta')=10000\ge11,u_3(\theta')=10000\ge12,u1â€‹(Î¸â€²)=9.9<10,u2â€‹(Î¸â€²)=10000â‰¥11,u3â€‹(Î¸â€²)=10000â‰¥12,

summing them up, we have

u1(Î¸â€²)u1(Î¸)+u2(Î¸â€²)u2(Î¸)+u3(Î¸â€²)u3(Î¸)>3=n\frac{u_1(\theta')}{u_1(\theta)}+\frac{u_2(\theta')}{u_2(\theta)}+\frac{u_3(\theta')}{u_3(\theta)}\gt3=nu1â€‹(Î¸)u1â€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹+u2â€‹(Î¸)u2â€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹+u3â€‹(Î¸)u3â€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹>3=n

Scaled factor âˆ£Sâˆ£/n|S|/nâˆ£Sâˆ£/n suggests some kind of proportionality here. Basically core-stability means there is no big benefit for agent to form a coalition.

Core means â€œno deviating subgroupâ€

Core stability is very strong, only exists in special cases.

Advantage

More fair than FedAvg. MMM is a very large integer.

Agent 1Agent 2Agent 3
Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹aaaaaaMâ‹…aM\cdot aMâ‹…a
Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹10a10a10a10a10a10a0.9Mâ‹…a0.9M\cdot a0.9Mâ‹…a

In FedAvg, Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹ is preferred, but not fair to Agent 1 and 2. (They have incentive to collide.)

Robustness to poor local data quality of agents.

â—Scaling the utility of any single agents does not change the core-stable allocation.

Core-Stability in FL

CoreFed exists in Linear Regression and Logistic Regression (Classification)

Approximate core stable predictor exists in Deep Neural Network.

Existence

ğŸ¤”Core-Stability exist in FL if:

  1. Utility function is continuous.

  2. The conical combination of utility functions is convex.

    âˆ€âŸ¨Î±1,â‹¯â€‰,Î±nâŸ©âˆˆRâ‰¥0n\forall\langle\alpha_1,\cdots,\alpha_n\rangle\in\mathbb R_{\ge0}^nâˆ€âŸ¨Î±1â€‹,â‹¯,Î±nâ€‹âŸ©âˆˆRâ‰¥0nâ€‹, the set C={Î¸âˆ£âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]Î±iui(Î¸)}C=\{\theta|\sum_{i\in[n]}\alpha_iu_i(\theta)\}C={Î¸âˆ£âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€‹Î±iâ€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)} is convex.

ğŸ¤”Important theorem: Kakutaniâ€™s Fixed Point Theorem: A set valued function Ï•:Dâ†’2D\phi:D\to2^DÏ•:Dâ†’2D admits a fixed point, i.e. âˆƒdâˆˆD\exist d\in DâˆƒdâˆˆD, s.t. dâˆˆÏ•(d)d\in\phi(d)dâˆˆÏ•(d), if

  1. DDD is non-empty, compact, and convex

Compact: The set is closed (It must contains all its boundary points), and bounded (It can be covered by a â€œsphereâ€ with certain radius)

Convex: A set is convex if, for any two points xxx and yyy in the set, the line segment connecting xxx and yyy also lies entirely within the set. Mathematically, for any x,yâˆˆSx,y\in Sx,yâˆˆS and any tâˆˆ[0,1]t \in [0, 1]tâˆˆ[0,1], the point: tx+(1âˆ’t)yâˆˆStx+(1âˆ’t)y\in Stx+(1âˆ’t)yâˆˆS.

  1. âˆ€dâˆˆD,Ï•(d)\forall d\in D,\phi(d)âˆ€dâˆˆD,Ï•(d) is non-empty, compact, and convex.
  2. Ï•(â‹…)\phi(\cdot)Ï•(â‹…) has a closed graph. i.e., âˆ€\forallâˆ€ sequence (di)iâˆˆN(d_i)_{i\in\mathbb N}(diâ€‹)iâˆˆNâ€‹ converging to dâˆ—d^*dâˆ— and (ei)iâˆˆN(e_i)_{i\in\mathbb N}(eiâ€‹)iâˆˆNâ€‹ converging to eâˆ—e^*eâˆ—, s.t. diâˆˆDd_i\in Ddiâ€‹âˆˆD and eiâˆˆÏ•(di)e_i\in\phi(d_i)eiâ€‹âˆˆÏ•(diâ€‹), we have eâˆ—âˆˆÏ•(dâˆ—)e^*\in\phi(d^*)eâˆ—âˆˆÏ•(dâˆ—).

Define Core-Stable Feasible Predictors

âˆ€Î¸âˆˆP\forall\theta\in Pâˆ€Î¸âˆˆP, Ï•(Î¸)={argâ¡maxâ¡dâˆˆPâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(d)ui(Î¸)}\phi(\theta)=\{\arg\max_{d\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(d)}{u_i(\theta)}\}Ï•(Î¸)={argmaxdâˆˆPâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)uiâ€‹(d)â€‹}.

Lemma 4.1: Let Î¸âˆˆP\theta\in PÎ¸âˆˆP be s.t. Î¸âˆˆÏ•(Î¸)\theta\in\phi(\theta)Î¸âˆˆÏ•(Î¸) (It is a fixed point). Then Î¸\thetaÎ¸ is a core-stable predictor.

Proof by contradiction.

By Takutaniâ€™s Theorem, it suffices to show that Ï•(â‹…)\phi(\cdot)Ï•(â‹…) has a closed graph, to ensure that it admits a fixed point.

Lemma 4.2: Ï•(â‹…)\phi(\cdot)Ï•(â‹…) has a closed graph.

Hard proof.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 1. In FL, where utilities are continuous and any conical combination of utilities is convex, a core-stable predictor exists.

âš ï¸If we change dâˆˆPd\in PdâˆˆP to dâˆˆB(Î¸,r)d\in\mathcal B(\theta, r)dâˆˆB(Î¸,r), if the two condition still holds within a radius of rrr of every point. The conditions tend to be true in DNN of small rrr. Then the predictor is locally core-stable.

Computation of Core-Stable Predictor

There is efficient way to compute core-stable predictor.

It is optima of convex program:

maximizeÂ L(Î¸)=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]logâ¡(ui(Î¸))Â orÂ âˆiâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸)subjectÂ toÂ Î¸âˆˆP\text{maximize }\mathcal L(\theta)=\sum_{i\in[n]}\log(u_i(\theta))\text{ or }\prod_{i\in[n]}u_i(\theta)\\\text{subject to }\theta\in PmaximizeÂ L(Î¸)=iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹log(uiâ€‹(Î¸))Â orÂ iâˆˆ[n]âˆâ€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸)subjectÂ toÂ Î¸âˆˆP

The object reminds me of Nash Social WelfareğŸ˜

Utility of each agent is concave, thus above program is convex. Thus this program is concave maximization subject to convex constraint.

ğŸ¤”Theorem 2. If uiu_iuiâ€‹ is concave for all iii, then any predictor Î¸âˆ—\theta^*Î¸âˆ— maximizes the convex program is core stable.

Proof by contradiction

âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ui(Î¸â€²)ui(Î¸âˆ—)â‰¤n.\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta^*)}\le n.iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹uiâ€‹(Î¸âˆ—)uiâ€‹(Î¸â€²)â€‹â‰¤n.

If Î¸âˆ—\theta^*Î¸âˆ— is not core-stable, there must exist Î¸â€²\theta'Î¸â€² and subset SSS, s.t.

å£è¯­è¡¨è¾¾ç»ƒä¹  Mit mÃ¸de med dansk kultur

Jeg oplevede dansk kultur for fÃ¸rste gang, da jeg kom til Danmark for at studere. Jeg har lagt mÃ¦rke til flere forskelle og ligheder mellem Danmark og mit hjemland. For eksempel bruger man i mit hjemland ofte â€˜Deâ€™, nÃ¥r man taler med Ã¦ldre eller folk, man ikke kender godt. I Danmark siger man bare â€˜duâ€™ til alle, og det gÃ¸r, at folk fÃ¸ler sig mere lige. Det synes jeg er meget spÃ¦ndende.

En anden stor forskel er tillid. I Danmark stoler folk meget pÃ¥ hinanden. Man ser ofte, at folk efterlader deres ting udenfor, uden at vÃ¦re bange for, at de bliver stjÃ¥let. I mit hjemland er vi mere forsigtige, fordi vi ikke har samme tillid. Jeg synes, det er godt, at der er sÃ¥ meget tillid her.

Noget andet, jeg har lagt mÃ¦rke til, er mÃ¥den, danskerne kommunikerer pÃ¥. I mit hjemland bruger vi ofte meget kropssprog, mens danskerne er mere rolige. Men de siger, hvad de mener, og det kan vÃ¦re lidt overraskende i starten. Jeg har ogsÃ¥ lÃ¦rt, at lighed er meget vigtigt i Danmark. BÃ¥de mÃ¦nd og kvinder deler husarbejde og bÃ¸rnepasning, hvilket er anderledes fra mit hjemland.

Hygge er ogsÃ¥ noget, der er meget typisk dansk. Det handler om at skabe en hyggelig og afslappet stemning, ofte med venner og familie. I mit hjemland er socialisering mere hÃ¸jlydt og aktiv, sÃ¥ hygge har vÃ¦ret en ny oplevelse for mig. Men jeg kan godt lide det.

Til sidst har jeg lagt mÃ¦rke til, at danskerne ikke altid er sÃ¥ gode til at tale om problemer. De vil hellere undgÃ¥ konflikter, hvilket er noget, jeg har skullet vÃ¦nne mig til. Men jeg synes, det er godt, at danskerne gÃ¥r op i tolerance og respekt for hinanden. Alle bliver behandlet pÃ¥ samme mÃ¥de, og det er noget, jeg virkelig har lÃ¦rt at sÃ¦tte pris pÃ¥.

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 7 Bounded Depth Boolean Circuits
entry.content:
What if Boolean circuits has bounded depth?

Depth of Boolean circuit: the length of a longest path from an input gate to an output gate.

Itâ€™s a model of parallel computation where depth corresponds to parallel time.

Parallel model of random access machine PRAM ç—›è‹¦çš„è®¡ç®—å‡ ä½•è¯¾çš„å›å¿†

ğŸ“–Definition of SIZEâˆ’DEPTHSIZE-DEPTHSIZEâˆ’DEPTH. Let S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N\to\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N and d:Nâ†’Nd:\mathbb N\to\mathbb Nd:Nâ†’N. SIZEâˆ’DEPTH(S(n),d(n))SIZE-DEPTH(S(n),d(n))SIZEâˆ’DEPTH(S(n),d(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) and depth O(d(n))O(d(n))O(d(n)).

ğŸ“–Definition of NCiNC^iNCi. For iâ‰¥0i\ge0iâ‰¥0, define NCi=SIZEâˆ’DEPTH(nO(1),logâ¡i(n))NC^i=SIZE-DEPTH(n^O(1),\log^i(n))NCi=SIZEâˆ’DEPTH(nO(1),logi(n)), and further define NC=âˆªiâ‰¥1NCiNC=\cup_{i\ge1}NC^iNC=âˆªiâ‰¥1â€‹NCi.

These circuit classes is restrict to polynomial size and poly-logarithmic depth.

By definition, NCâŠ†P/polyNC\subseteq P/polyNCâŠ†P/poly, hence ULâˆ’NCâŠ†PU_L-NC\subseteq PULâ€‹âˆ’NCâŠ†P.

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆå‘¢ï¼Ÿå›é¡¾å®šä¹‰ P/poly=â‹ƒk>0SIZE(nk)P/poly=\bigcup_{k\gt0}SIZE(n^k)P/poly=â‹ƒk>0â€‹SIZE(nk)ï¼Œå‘ç°å®ƒçš„å¤šäº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ·±åº¦çš„é™åˆ¶ã€‚

In fact PâŠ†Ì¸NCP\not\subseteq NCPî€ âŠ†NC is expected to hold. This means not all languages in PPP can benefit greatly from parallelism.

General Boolean Circuits

Consider Boolean circuits that allows arbitrary fanin gate and more general functions than AND,OR,NOTAND, OR, NOTAND,OR,NOT.

General definition of Boolean circuit. A Boolean circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of the following:

  • An underlying directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) (multiple arcs is allowed)
  • A labeling â„“\ellâ„“ of the nodes of VVV.
  • A linear ordering on the arcs AAA of VVV.
  • A choice of mmm output gates o1,â‹¯â€‰,omâˆˆVo_1,\cdots,o_m\in Vo1â€‹,â‹¯,omâ€‹âˆˆV

The size of CCC is the number of wires. The labelling function â„“\ellâ„“ should satisfy the following for all gates ggg:

  • If the fanin of ggg is 000, then â„“(g)âˆˆ{0,1,x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn,x1â€¾,â‹¯â€‰,xnâ€¾}\ell(g)\in\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n,\overline{x_1},\cdots,\overline{x_n}\}â„“(g)âˆˆ{0,1,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹,x1â€‹â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹â€‹}.
  • If the fanin of ggg is kâ‰¥1k\ge1kâ‰¥1, then â„“(g)=fg\ell(g)=f_gâ„“(g)=fgâ€‹ where fg:{0,1}kâ†’{0,1}f_g:\{0,1\}^k\to\{0,1\}fgâ€‹:{0,1}kâ†’{0,1} is an kkk-ary Boolean function.

CCC compute a Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}mf:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}^mf:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}m in a natural way.

Boolean functions with k-ary

AND(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=z_1\and\cdots\and z_k\\OR(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=z_1\or\cdots\or z_k\\MOD_m(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\not\equiv0\mod m\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\equiv0\mod m\end{cases}

MOD2MOD_2MOD2â€‹ is the same as the xor-sum.

The major voting function MAJMAJMAJ:

MAJ(z1,â‹¯â€‰,zk)={1Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kziâ‰¥k20Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kzi<k2MAJ(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\ge\frac{k}{2}\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\lt\frac{k}{2}\end{cases}MAJ(z1â€‹,â‹¯,zkâ€‹)={1Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹ziâ€‹â‰¥2kâ€‹0Â ifÂ âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹ziâ€‹<2kâ€‹â€‹

Let w=(w1,â‹¯â€‰,wk)âˆˆRkw=(w_1,\cdots,w_k)\in\mathbb R^kw=(w1â€‹,â‹¯,wkâ€‹)âˆˆRk be weights and tâˆˆRt\in\mathbb RtâˆˆR be a threshold. Then THRw,tTHR_{w,t}THRw,tâ€‹ is defined:

Several Circuit Classes

ğŸ“–Definition of ACiAC^iACi. For iâ‰¥0i\ge0iâ‰¥0, ACiAC^iACi is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of polynomial size and depth O(logâ¡in)O(\log^in)O(login) using unbounded fanin ANDANDAND and OROROR gates.

log-space can be roughly the same as log-depth circuits.

Functions and Reductions

Boolean circuit is fixed number of inputs, we consider output is also a bounded function of the length of input.

ğŸ“–Definition of length-respecting. A function f:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ—f:\{0,1\}^*\to\{0,1\}^*f:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}âˆ— is length-respecting if for all x,yâˆˆ{0,1}âˆ—x,y\in\{0,1\}^*x,yâˆˆ{0,1}âˆ—, we have âˆ£xâˆ£=âˆ£yâˆ£â‡’âˆ£f(x)âˆ£=âˆ£f(y)âˆ£|x|=|y|\Rarr|f(x)|=|f(y)|âˆ£xâˆ£=âˆ£yâˆ£â‡’âˆ£f(x)âˆ£=âˆ£f(y)âˆ£.

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 6 Randomized Computation
entry.content:
What if Turing machine models have access to a source of randomness?

This would allow to compute more in same time/space, at the price of possibly not giving correct answer with small probability.

Current consensus: Randomization only gives

  • Polynomial saving in time
  • Constant factor saving in space

Because of hardness-based pseudo-random generator.

Exponential time: E=DTIME(2O(n))=ULâˆ’SIZE(2O(n))E=DTIME(2^{O(n)})=U_L-SIZE(2^{O(n)})E=DTIME(2O(n))=ULâ€‹âˆ’SIZE(2O(n)). (By corollary 2)

Recall that SIZE(2n/n)SIZE(2^n/n)SIZE(2n/n) includes every Boolean function on nnn variables, making non-uniform inclusion EâŠ†SIZE(2O(n))E\subseteq SIZE(2^{O(n)})EâŠ†SIZE(2O(n)).

Corresponding randomized complexity class BPPBPPBPP.

Theorem 33 (Impagliazzo and Wigderson). If there exists LâˆˆEL\in ELâˆˆE s.t. for every nnn and every Boolean circuit CCC computing LLL on input length nnn, the size of CCC must be 2Î©(n)2^{\Omega(n)}2Î©(n), then P=BPPP=BPPP=BPP.

Probabilistic Turing Machines

Give a probabilistic Turing machine an extra read-only and read-once tape which is pre-initialized with uniform and independent random bits. The tape head is allow to only stop or move forward.

Thus everything related to the Turing machines becomes a random variable.

Different kinds of Errors

Zero-sided error aka Las Vegas computation: Turing machine halt in a state â€œ?â€ with small probability and require correct answer otherwise.

One-sided error: Turing machine may produce false negatives.

Two-sided error: Turing machine may produce false negatives and false positives.

ğŸ“–Definition 19. Let MMM be a probabilistic Turing machine and LLL a language.

  • MMM computes LLL with zero-sided error if for all xxx we have Prâ¡[M(x)=?]â‰¤14\Pr[M(x)=?]\le\frac{1}{4}Pr[M(x)=?]â‰¤41â€‹, that M(x)âˆˆ{yes,?}M(x)\in\{yes,?\}M(x)âˆˆ{yes,?} when xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL, and that M(x)âˆˆ{no,?}M(x)\in\{no,?\}M(x)âˆˆ{no,?} when xâˆˆÌ¸Lx\not\in Lxî€ âˆˆL.
  • MMM computes LLL with one-sided error if for all xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL we have Prâ¡[M(x)=yes]â‰¥34\Pr[M(x)=yes]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=yes]â‰¥43â€‹ and for all xâˆˆÌ¸Lx\not\in Lxî€ âˆˆL we have M(x)=noM(x)=noM(x)=no.
  • MMM computes LLL with two-sided error if for all xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL we have Prâ¡[M(x)=yes]â‰¥34\Pr[M(x)=yes]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=yes]â‰¥43â€‹ and for all xâˆˆÌ¸Lx\not\in Lxî€ âˆˆL we have Prâ¡[M(x)=no]â‰¥34\Pr[M(x)=no]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=no]â‰¥43â€‹.

ğŸ“–Definition 20. Let T:Nâ†’NT:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NT:Nâ†’N and S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N be functions with T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n.

  • Then ZPTIME(T(n))ZPTIME(T(n))ZPTIME(T(n)), RTIME(T(n))RTIME(T(n))RTIME(T(n)) and BPTIME(T(n))BPTIME(T(n))BPTIME(T(n)) are the classes of languages computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded probabilistic Turing machine with zero-sided error, one-sided error and two-sided error respectively.
  • ZPSPACE(S(n))ZPSPACE(S(n))ZPSPACE(S(n)), RSPACE(S(n))RSPACE(S(n))RSPACE(S(n)) and BPSPACE(S(n))BPSPACE(S(n))BPSPACE(S(n)) are the classes of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded probabilistic Turing machine that always halt having zero-sided error, one-sided error and two-sided error respectively.

For space bounded randomized classes, we assume that the Turing machine always halts! Because otherwise these three classes would end up containing NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))!

Define log-space/polynomial time bounded classes:

ZPL=ZPSPACE(logâ¡n)RP=RSPACE(logâ¡n)BPL=BPSPACE(logâ¡n)ZPP=ZPTIME(nO(1))RP=RTIME(nO(1))BPP=BPTIME(nO(1))ZPL=ZPSPACE(\log n)\\RP=RSPACE(\log n)\\BPL=BPSPACE(\log n)\\ZPP=ZPTIME(n^{O(1)})\\RP=RTIME(n^{O(1)})\\BPP=BPTIME(n^{O(1)})ZPL=ZPSPACE(logn)RP=RSPACE(logn)BPL=BPSPACE(logn)ZPP=ZPTIME(nO(1))RP=RTIME(nO(1))BPP=BPTIME(nO(1))

Trivially, LâŠ†ZPLâŠ†RLâŠ†BPLL\subseteq ZPL\subseteq RL\subseteq BPLLâŠ†ZPLâŠ†RLâŠ†BPL; PâŠ†ZPPâŠ†RPâŠ†BPPP\subseteq ZPP\subseteq RP\subseteq BPPPâŠ†ZPPâŠ†RPâŠ†BPP.

Itâ€™s also easy to see that RLâŠ†NLRL\subseteq NLRLâŠ†NL and RPâŠ†NPRP\subseteq NPRPâŠ†NP.

Simple upper bound for BPPBPPBPP (not tight): similar to theorem 10, BPPâŠ†PSPACEBPP\subseteq PSPACEBPPâŠ†PSPACE.

For BPLBPLBPL, BPLâŠ†DSPACE(logâ¡3/2n)BPL\subseteq DSPACE(\log^{3/2}n)BPLâŠ†DSPACE(log3/2n).

Success Amplification

Error probability of 1/41/41/4 is large, but we can reduce it by independently running multiple times.

For zero-sided error, we wonâ€™t stop until we get non-unknown answer.

For one-sided error, if some trial accepts, we accept. otherwise we reject.

For two-sided error, we decided the answer by the majority of trials.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 3. Let X1,â‹¯â€‰,XkX_1,\cdots,X_kX1â€‹,â‹¯,Xkâ€‹ be independent Boolean variables s.t. Prâ¡[Xi=1]â‰¥Ïµ\Pr[X_i=1]\ge\epsilonPr[Xiâ€‹=1]â‰¥Ïµ. Then

Prâ¡[âˆ€i:Xi=0]<expâ¡(âˆ’kÏµ)\Pr[\forall i:X_i=0]\lt\exp(-k\epsilon)Pr[âˆ€i:Xiâ€‹=0]<exp(âˆ’kÏµ)

By independence,

Prâ¡[âˆ€i:Xi=0]=âˆiPrâ¡[Xi=0]<(1âˆ’Ïµ)kâ‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’kÏµ).\Pr[\forall i:X_i=0]=\prod_i\Pr[X_i=0]\lt(1-\epsilon)^k\le\exp(-k\epsilon).Pr[âˆ€i:Xiâ€‹=0]=iâˆâ€‹Pr[Xiâ€‹=0]<(1âˆ’Ïµ)kâ‰¤exp(âˆ’kÏµ).

(by 1+xâ‰¤expâ¡(x)1+x\le\exp(x)1+xâ‰¤exp(x))

Apply this to zero-sided and one-sided errors:

  • Define XiX_iXiâ€‹ to indicate whether trial iii gives the correct output.
  • Instead of having error probability 1/41/41/4, we actually assume that error probability for once is less than 1âˆ’1p(n)1-\frac{1}{p(n)}1âˆ’p(n)1â€‹ and still achieve error probability expâ¡(âˆ’q(n))\exp(-q(n))exp(âˆ’q(n)) for all by running k=p(n)q(n)k=p(n)q(n)k=p(n)q(n) trials, which is polynomial number.

For two-sided error:

ğŸ¤”Lemma 4 (Chernoff-Hoeffding Bound). Let XXX be the sum of kkk independent Boolean random variables. Assume Î¼Lâ‰¤E[X]â‰¤Î¼H\mu_L\le\mathbb E[X]\le\mu_HÎ¼Lâ€‹â‰¤E[X]â‰¤Î¼Hâ€‹, t>0t>0t>0. Then

Prâ¡[X<Î¼Lâˆ’t]â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’2t2/k),Prâ¡[X>Î¼H+t]â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’2t2/k).\Pr[X<\mu_L-t]\le\exp(-2t^2/k),\\\Pr[X>\mu_H+t]\le\exp(-2t^2/k).Pr[X<Î¼Lâ€‹âˆ’t]â‰¤exp(âˆ’2t2/k),Pr[X>Î¼Hâ€‹+t]â‰¤exp(âˆ’2t2/k).

We define the random indicator XiX_iXiâ€‹ to indicate whether trial iii gave correct output. We assume that Prâ¡[Xi=1]â‰¥12+Ïµ\Pr[X_i=1]\ge\frac{1}{2}+\epsilonPr[Xiâ€‹=1]â‰¥21â€‹+Ïµ and kkk is odd. Let X=âˆ‘i=1kXiX=\sum_{i=1}^kX_iX=âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹Xiâ€‹, we have E[X]â‰¥k2+kÏµ\mathbb E[X]\ge\frac{k}{2}+k\epsilonE[X]â‰¥2kâ€‹+kÏµ. Applying Chernoff-Hoeffding bound, we have

Prâ¡[X<k2]=Prâ¡[X<Î¼Lâˆ’kÏµ]â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’2(kÏµ)2/k)=expâ¡(âˆ’2kÏµ2)\Pr[X<\frac{k}{2}]=\Pr[X<\mu_L-k\epsilon]\le\exp(-2(k\epsilon)^2/k)\\=\exp(-2k\epsilon^2)Pr[X<2kâ€‹]=Pr[X<Î¼Lâ€‹âˆ’kÏµ]â‰¤exp(âˆ’2(kÏµ)2/k)=exp(âˆ’2kÏµ2)

using Î¼L=k2+kÏµ\mu_L=\frac{k}{2}+k\epsilonÎ¼Lâ€‹=2kâ€‹+kÏµ. Instead of have error probability 1/41/41/4, we assume error probability for once just less than 1/2âˆ’1/p(n)1/2-1/p(n)1/2âˆ’1/p(n) and achieve error probability expâ¡(âˆ’q(n))\exp(-q(n))exp(âˆ’q(n)) by running k=p(n)2q(n)2k=\frac{p(n)^2q(n)}{2}k=2p(n)2q(n)â€‹ independent trials.

These analysis applies to both polynomial-time bounded and log-space bounded randomized complexity classes.

Polynomial Identity Testing

Donâ€™t know:

  1. Whether randomized classes have complete problem;
  2. Any hierarchy results for randomized classes.

PIT

Polynomial Identity Testing (PIT): Testing whether a polynomial is identically zero.

PIT problem is efficiently solvable in randomized polynomial time but not known to be solvable deterministically in polynomial time.

ğŸ“–Definition 21 (Arithmetic circuit). An arithmetic circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of the following:

  1. A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) where the in-degree of every node is either 000 or 222.
  2. A labeling â„“\ellâ„“ for the nodes VVV.
  3. A choice of mmm outputs gates o1,â‹¯â€‰,omâˆˆVo_1,\cdots,o_m\in Vo1â€‹,â‹¯,omâ€‹âˆˆV.

Nodes VVV corresponds to gates, edges AAA corresponds to wires. Nodes of in-degree 000 are input gates. The labeling function satisfies âˆ€\forallâˆ€ gates ggg:

  1. If fanin of ggg is 000, â„“(g)âˆˆ{1,x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\ell(g)\in\{1,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}â„“(g)âˆˆ{1,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹}.
  2. If fanin of ggg is 222, â„“(g)âˆˆ{+,Ã—,âˆ’}\ell(g)\in\{+,\times,-\}â„“(g)âˆˆ{+,Ã—,âˆ’}.

æ•…æ„ä¸è¯´äººè¯â€¦â€¦å°±æ˜¯æŠŠå¤šé¡¹å¼åˆ†è§£æˆå¤šå±‚äºŒå…ƒè¿ç®—ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªå¤šé¡¹å¼å°±ç›¸å½“äºåªæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªè¾“å‡ºå£çš„ç®—æœ¯ç”µè·¯ã€‚

Such an arithmetic circuit compute a polynomial pâˆˆR[x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn]p\in R[x_1,\cdots,x_n]pâˆˆR[x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹] for any Abelian ring RRR. é˜¿è´å°”ç¯

Usually we consider arithmetic circuits w.r.t. ring.

AFIT

aka Arithmetic formula identity testing

A variant of PIT: input polynomial is given by an arithmetic formula.

Instance: Arithmetic formula computing the polynomial P(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)âˆˆZ[x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn]P(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\in\mathbb Z[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)âˆˆZ[x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹].

Question: Is P(x)â‰¡0P(x)\equiv0P(x)â‰¡0?

A simple randomized algorithm: simply choose number a1,â‹¯â€‰,anâˆˆ{1,2,â‹¯â€‰,4m}a_1,\cdots,a_n\in\{1,2,\cdots,4m\}a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹âˆˆ{1,2,â‹¯,4m} independently and uniformly at random, where mmm is the size of the given formula, evaluate P(a1,â‹¯â€‰,an)P(a_1,\cdots, a_n)P(a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹) and answer accordingly.

Using Schwartz-Zippel lemma to analyze error probability.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 5 (Schwartz-Zippel lemma). Let F\mathbb FF be a field, let P(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)âˆˆF[x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn]P(x_1,\cdots, x_n)\in\mathbb F[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)âˆˆF[x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹] be a non-zero polynomial of total degree at most ddd. Let SâŠ†FS\subseteq\mathbb FSâŠ†F, and pick a1,â‹¯â€‰,anâˆˆSa_1,\cdots, a_n\in Sa1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹âˆˆS independently and uniformly at random. Then

Prâ¡[P(a1,â‹¯â€‰,an)=0]â‰¤dâˆ£Sâˆ£.\Pr[P(a_1,\cdots,a_n)=0]\le\frac{d}{|S|}.Pr[P(a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹)=0]â‰¤âˆ£Sâˆ£dâ€‹.

Proof by induction on nnn.

So the error probability is decided by mmm, at most 1/41/41/4.

ğŸ¯Theorem 45. AFITâˆˆcoRPAFIT\in coRPAFITâˆˆcoRP.

æ²¡å¤ªæ‡‚è¿™ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†

Sample from 1,â‹¯â€‰,m1,\cdots,m1,â‹¯,m is equivalent to sample kkk times from 1,â‹¯â€‰,2âŒˆlogâ¡2mâŒ‰1,\cdots,2^{\lceil\log_2m\rceil}1,â‹¯,2âŒˆlog2â€‹mâŒ‰. k=Ï‰(logâ¡n)k=\omega(\log n)k=Ï‰(logn).

ACIT

aka arithmetic circuit identity testing

Instance: Arithmetic circuit computing the polynomial P(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)âˆˆZ[x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn]P(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\in\mathbb Z[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)âˆˆZ[x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹].

Question: Is P(x)â‰¡0P(x)\equiv0P(x)â‰¡0?

Circuit of size mmm has at most mmm multiplication gates. The degree of the polynomial computed is at most 2m2^m2m. The same approach as in arithmetic formula calls for draw random number from 1,â‹¯â€‰,2m+21,\cdots,2^{m+2}1,â‹¯,2m+2. (exponential!)

To remedy this, we switch to modular arithmetic with randomly chosen prime modulus. Use prime number theorem to analyze error probability.

Let Ï€(x)\pi(x)Ï€(x) be the number of prime number less than xxx. By prime number theory,

Ï€(x)âˆ¼xlnâ¡x.\pi(x)\sim\frac{x}{\ln x}.Ï€(x)âˆ¼lnxxâ€‹.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 6. For all m>1m>1m>1, we have Ï€(2m)â‰¥2mm\pi(2^m)\ge\frac{2^m}{m}Ï€(2m)â‰¥m2mâ€‹.

ğŸ¤”ğŸ¯Theorem 35. ACITâˆˆcoRPACIT\in coRPACITâˆˆcoRP.

Det kan jeg ikke forstÃ¥r

An Alternative Characterization of Time Bounded Classes

We have alternative characterization of BPPBPPBPP. Also there are similar alternatives of ZPPZPPZPP and RPRPRP.

Proposition 4. Let LLL be a language. Then LâˆˆBPPL\in BPPLâˆˆBPP iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆPL'\in PLâ€²âˆˆP s.t. âˆ€x\forall xâˆ€x:

xâˆˆLâ‡’Prâ¡yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²]â‰¥34xâˆˆÌ¸Lâ‡’Prâ¡yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆÌ¸Lâ€²]â‰¥34x\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']\ge\frac{3}{4}\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\not\in L']\ge\frac{3}{4}xâˆˆLâ‡’yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)Prâ€‹[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²]â‰¥43â€‹xî€ âˆˆLâ‡’yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)Prâ€‹[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©î€ âˆˆLâ€²]â‰¥43â€‹

We say that the randomized computation uses q(âˆ£xâˆ£)q(|x|)q(âˆ£xâˆ£) random bits.

Using success amplification a randomized algorithm using RRR random bits and having error probability less than 1/41/41/4 can be transformed to a randomized algorithm using kRkRkR random bits and having error probability less than expâ¡(âˆ’k/8)\exp(-k/8)exp(âˆ’k/8) by running kkk trials and taking the majority vote.

Randomized Computation and the Polynomial-time Hierarchy

By definition, RPâŠ†NPRP\subseteq NPRPâŠ†NP.

But we donâ€™t know whether BPPâŠ†NPBPP\subseteq NPBPPâŠ†NP or NPâŠ†BPPNP\subseteq BPPNPâŠ†BPP.

We just guess: BPP=PBPP=PBPP=P thus BPPâŠ†NPBPP\subseteq NPBPPâŠ†NP.

But we can prove that BPPBPPBPP is contained in the second level of polynomial-time hierarchy.

ğŸ¯Theorem 36. BPPâŠ†Î£2Pâˆ©Î 2PBPP\subseteq \Sigma_2^P\cap\Pi_2^PBPPâŠ†Î£2Pâ€‹âˆ©Î 2Pâ€‹.

Prove that BPPâŠ†Î£2PBPP\subseteq\Sigma_2^PBPPâŠ†Î£2Pâ€‹. From this also we get BPPâŠ†Î 2PBPP\subseteq\Pi_2^PBPPâŠ†Î 2Pâ€‹.

  • Let LâˆˆBPPL\in BPPLâˆˆBPP. We have a polynomial q(n)q(n)q(n) and a language Lâ€²âˆˆPL'\in PLâ€²âˆˆP s.t. for all xxx we have

    xâˆˆLâ‡’Prâ¡yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²]â‰¥1âˆ’12q(âˆ£xâˆ£),xâˆˆÌ¸Lâ‡’Prâ¡yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²]<1âˆ’12q(âˆ£xâˆ£).x\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']\ge1-\frac{1}{2q(|x|)},\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']<1-\frac{1}{2q(|x|)}.xâˆˆLâ‡’yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)Prâ€‹[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²]â‰¥1âˆ’2q(âˆ£xâˆ£)1â€‹,xî€ âˆˆLâ‡’yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)Prâ€‹[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²]<1âˆ’2q(âˆ£xâˆ£)1â€‹.

  • Let m=q(âˆ£xâˆ£)m=q(|x|)m=q(âˆ£xâˆ£). For given xxx, we define Sx={yâˆˆ{0,1}mâˆ£âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²}S_x=\{y\in\{0,1\}^m|\langle x,y\rangle\in L'\}Sxâ€‹={yâˆˆ{0,1}mâˆ£âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²}. Thus, for all xxx we have

    xâˆˆLâ‡’âˆ£Sxâˆ£â‰¥(1âˆ’12m)2m,xâˆˆÌ¸Lâ‡’âˆ£Sxâˆ£<12m2m.x\in L\Rarr|S_x|\ge(1-\frac{1}{2m})2^m,\\x\not\in L\Rarr|S_x|<\frac{1}{2m}2^m.xâˆˆLâ‡’âˆ£Sxâ€‹âˆ£â‰¥(1âˆ’2m1â€‹)2m,xî€ âˆˆLâ‡’âˆ£Sxâ€‹âˆ£<2m1â€‹2m.

    Claim that xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL iff

    âˆƒu1,â‹¯â€‰,umâˆˆ{0,1}mâˆ€râˆˆ{0,1}m:â‹i=1mâŸ¨x,uiâŠ•râŸ©âˆˆLâ€²,\exist u_1,\cdots, u_m\in\{0,1\}^m\forall r\in\{0,1\}^m:\\\bigvee_{i=1}^m\langle x,u_i\oplus r\rangle\in L',âˆƒu1â€‹,â‹¯,umâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1}mâˆ€râˆˆ{0,1}m:i=1â‹mâ€‹âŸ¨x,uiâ€‹âŠ•râŸ©âˆˆLâ€²,

    where uiâŠ•ru_i\oplus ruiâ€‹âŠ•r denote the coordinate-wise exclusive-or. ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯åæ ‡æˆ–è¿ç®—ï¼Ÿ

  • This shows that LâˆˆÎ£2PL\in\Sigma_2^PLâˆˆÎ£2Pâ€‹ since this can be done in polynomial time.

It remains to prove the predicate is equivalent to â‹ƒi=1muiâŠ•Sx={0,1}m\bigcup_{i=1}^mu_i\oplus S_x=\{0,1\}^mâ‹ƒi=1mâ€‹uiâ€‹âŠ•Sxâ€‹={0,1}m.

Randomized Computation and Boolean Circuits

Everything that can be computed in polynomial-time by randomized algorithm can also be computed using Boolean circuits.

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 5 The Polynomoial-Time Hierarchy
entry.content:
Idea: arithmetic hierarchy from recursion theory.

Halting problem HALTHALTHALT is a recursive enumerable language that is undecidable.

The polynomial-time hierarchy considers polynomial time and SATSATSAT instead of HALTHALTHALT.

Oracle Turing Machines

An oracle Turing machine M?M^?M? is equipped with an additional tape, the query tape, and has three new special states qask,qyes,qnoq_{ask},q_{yes},q_{no}qaskâ€‹,qyesâ€‹,qnoâ€‹. The query tape is a write-only tape.

The operation of M?M^?M? is defined relative to an oracle language AAA.

Denote M?M^?M? together with oracle language AAA by MAM^AMA.

Whenever MAM^AMA enters the state qaskq_{ask}qaskâ€‹:

  • Let zzz be the string of symbols written to the query tape. The query tape is reinitialized to a black tape.
  • If zâˆˆAz\in AzâˆˆA, computation resumes in the state qyesq_{yes}qyesâ€‹.
  • If zâˆˆÌ¸Az\not\in Azî€ âˆˆA, computation resumes in the state qnoq_{no}qnoâ€‹.

Define timeMA(x)time_{M^A}(x)timeMAâ€‹(x) and spaceMA(x)space_{M^A}(x)spaceMAâ€‹(x) for an oracle Turing machine with an oracle language AAA to be the number of computation steps and number of cells of work tape used during computation on input xxx. The same way we define time-bounded and space-bounded oracle Turing machines.

Then we need to define oracle versions of complexity classes. Straightforward to define time-bounded complexity classes, but be careful to define space-bounded complexity classes.

DTIMEA(T(n)),DSPACEA(S(n)),NTIMEA(T(n))DTIME^A(T(n)),DSPACE^A(S(n)),NTIME^A(T(n))DTIMEA(T(n)),DSPACEA(S(n)),NTIMEA(T(n)).

â—Problem for non-deterministic space-bounded oracle Turing machine: it may write very long strings to the oracle tape.

Solution: Requiring the oracle Turing machine to behave deterministically in the time between writing the first symbol to the oracle tape and making the oracle query. (deterministic oracle access)

Thus we define NSPACEA(S(n))NSPACE^A(S(n))NSPACEA(S(n)) as the class of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded non-deterministic oracle Turing machine with deterministic oracle access to oracle AAA.

The definition can be extended to other complexity classes.

PAP^APA and NPANP^ANPA for any oracle language AAA.

The oracle may be chosen from some class of languages. Let C\mathcal CC be a class of languages.

DTIMEC(T(n))=â‹ƒAâˆˆCDTIMEA(T(n))DTIME^\mathcal C(T(n))=\bigcup_{A\in\mathcal C}DTIME^A(T(n))DTIMEC(T(n))=AâˆˆCâ‹ƒâ€‹DTIMEA(T(n))

Similarly we have DSPACEC(T(n))DSPACE^\mathcal C(T(n))DSPACEC(T(n)), NTIMEC(T(n))NTIME^\mathcal C(T(n))NTIMEC(T(n)) and NSPACEC(T(n))NSPACE^\mathcal C(T(n))NSPACEC(T(n)).

This again extends to all other complexity classes such as PNPP^{NP}PNP.

Turing Reductions

ğŸ“–Definition 17 (Turing reductions). Let L1L_1L1â€‹ and L2L_2L2â€‹ be languages. We say that L1L_1L1â€‹ log-space Turing machine reduces to L2L_2L2â€‹ (L1â‰¤Tlogâ¡L2L_1\le_T^{\log}L_2L1â€‹â‰¤Tlogâ€‹L2â€‹), if L1âˆˆLL2L_1\in L^{L_2}L1â€‹âˆˆLL2â€‹. Similarly we say L1L_1L1â€‹ polynomial time Turing reduces to L2L_2L2â€‹ (L1â‰¤TPL2L_1\le_T^PL_2L1â€‹â‰¤TPâ€‹L2â€‹), if L1âˆˆPL2L_1\in P^{L_2}L1â€‹âˆˆPL2â€‹.

It also satisfies transitivity.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 2. Transitivity.

  • L1â‰¤Tlogâ¡L2,L2â‰¤Tlogâ¡L3â‡’L1â‰¤Tlogâ¡L3L_1\le_T^{\log}L_2,L_2\le_T^{\log}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_T^{\log}L_3L1â€‹â‰¤Tlogâ€‹L2â€‹,L2â€‹â‰¤Tlogâ€‹L3â€‹â‡’L1â€‹â‰¤Tlogâ€‹L3â€‹
  • L1â‰¤TPL2,L2â‰¤TPL3â‡’L1â‰¤TPL3L_1\le_T^{P}L_2,L_2\le_T^{P}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_T^{P}L_3L1â€‹â‰¤TPâ€‹L2â€‹,L2â€‹â‰¤TPâ€‹L3â€‹â‡’L1â€‹â‰¤TPâ€‹L3â€‹

ğŸ¤”Proposition 3. The class L,NL,P,PSPACE,EXPL,NL,P,PSPACE,EXPL,NL,P,PSPACE,EXP are all closed under log-space Turing reductions. The class P,PSPACE,EXPP,PSPACE,EXPP,PSPACE,EXP are all closed under polynomial-time Turing machine.

The Polynomial-time Hierarchy via Oracles and Quantifiers

For a class of language C\mathcal CC, denote coCco\mathcal CcoC the class of complements of languages of C\mathcal CC.

coC={Lâ€¾âˆ£LâˆˆC}co\mathcal C=\{\overline L|L\in\mathcal C\}coC={Lâˆ£LâˆˆC}

ğŸ“–Definition 18 (polynomial-time hierarchy). Let Î”0P=Î£0P=Î 0P=P\Delta_0^P=\Sigma_0^P=\Pi_0^P=PÎ”0Pâ€‹=Î£0Pâ€‹=Î 0Pâ€‹=P. For iâ‰¥0i\ge0iâ‰¥0, define further Î”i+1P=PÎ£iP\Delta_{i+1}^P=P^{\Sigma_i^P}Î”i+1Pâ€‹=PÎ£iPâ€‹, Î£i+1P=NPÎ£iP\Sigma_{i+1}^P=NP^{\Sigma_i^P}Î£i+1Pâ€‹=NPÎ£iPâ€‹ and Î i+1P=coNPÎ£iP\Pi_{i+1}^P=coNP^{\Sigma_i^P}Î i+1Pâ€‹=coNPÎ£iPâ€‹. Finally, let Polynomial Hierarchy PH=â‹ƒiâ‰¥0Î£iPPH=\bigcup_{i\ge0}\Sigma_i^PPH=â‹ƒiâ‰¥0â€‹Î£iPâ€‹.

The classes Î”iP,Î£iP,Î iP\Delta_i^P,\Sigma_i^P,\Pi_i^PÎ”iPâ€‹,Î£iPâ€‹,Î iPâ€‹ are said to make up level iii of the polynomial-time hierarchy, and PHPHPH denotes the entire polynomial-time hierarchy.

Note that Î”1P=PP=P\Delta_1^P=P^P=PÎ”1Pâ€‹=PP=P, Î£1P=NPP=NP\Sigma_1^P=NP^P=NPÎ£1Pâ€‹=NPP=NP, Î 1P=coNPP=coNP\Pi_1^P=coNP^P=coNPÎ 1Pâ€‹=coNPP=coNP.

On second level, we have PNP,NPNP,coNPNPP^{NP}, NP^{NP}, coNP^{NP}PNP,NPNP,coNPNP, continuing ad infimum.

Straightforward:

Î”iPâŠ†Î£iPâˆ©Î iPâŠ†Î£iPâˆªÎ iPâŠ†Î”i+1P\Delta_i^P\subseteq\Sigma_i^P\cap\Pi_i^P\subseteq\Sigma_i^P\cup\Pi_i^P\subseteq\Delta_{i+1}^PÎ”iPâ€‹âŠ†Î£iPâ€‹âˆ©Î iPâ€‹âŠ†Î£iPâ€‹âˆªÎ iPâ€‹âŠ†Î”i+1Pâ€‹

ğŸ¯Theorem 27. PHâŠ†PSPACEPH\subseteq PSPACEPHâŠ†PSPACE.

Using polynomial space simply simulate the non-deterministic Turing machine same way as in proof of Theorem 10.

Then prove an equivalent definition of the classes Î£iP\Sigma_i^PÎ£iPâ€‹ and Î iP\Pi_i^PÎ iPâ€‹ in terms of quantifiers.

ğŸ¯Theorem 28. Let LLL be any language and let iâ‰¥1i\ge1iâ‰¥1. Then LâˆˆÎ£iPL\in\Sigma_i^PLâˆˆÎ£iPâ€‹ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆÎ iâˆ’1PL'\in\Pi_{i-1}^PLâ€²âˆˆÎ iâˆ’1Pâ€‹ s.t.

\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\exist y:|y|\le q(|x|)\and\langle x,y\rangle\in L'].

çœ‹ä¸æ‡‚äº†ã€‚

ğŸ¤”Corollary 3. Let LLL be any language and let iâ‰¥1i\ge1iâ‰¥1. Then LâˆˆÎ iPL\in\Pi_i^PLâˆˆÎ iPâ€‹ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆÎ£iâˆ’1PL'\in\Sigma_{i-1}^PLâ€²âˆˆÎ£iâˆ’1Pâ€‹ s.t.

âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆ€y:âˆ£yâˆ£â‰¤q(âˆ£xâˆ£)â‡’âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²].\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\forall y:|y|\le q(|x|)\Rarr\langle x,y\rangle\in L'].âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆ€y:âˆ£yâˆ£â‰¤q(âˆ£xâˆ£)â‡’âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²].

ğŸ¤”Corollary 4. Let LLL be any language and let iâ‰¥1i\ge1iâ‰¥1. Then LâˆˆÎ£iPL\in\Sigma_i^PLâˆˆÎ£iPâ€‹ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆPL'\in PLâ€²âˆˆP s.t.

âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆƒqy1âˆ€qy2â‹¯Qiqyi:âŸ¨x,y1,y2,â‹¯â€‰,yiâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²],\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\exist^qy_1\forall^qy_2\cdots Q_i^qy_i:\langle x,y_1,y_2,\cdots,y_i\rangle\in L'],âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆƒqy1â€‹âˆ€qy2â€‹â‹¯Qiqâ€‹yiâ€‹:âŸ¨x,y1â€‹,y2â€‹,â‹¯,yiâ€‹âŸ©âˆˆLâ€²],

where QiQ_iQiâ€‹ is âˆƒ\existâˆƒ if iii is odd, and âˆ€\forallâˆ€ if iii is even. Likewise, LâˆˆÎ iPL\in\Pi_i^PLâˆˆÎ iPâ€‹ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆPL'\in PLâ€²âˆˆP s.t.

âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆ€qy1âˆƒqy2â‹¯Qiqyi:âŸ¨x,y1,y2,â‹¯â€‰,yiâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²],\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\forall^qy_1\exist^qy_2\cdots Q_i^qy_i:\langle x,y_1,y_2,\cdots,y_i\rangle\in L'],âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆ€qy1â€‹âˆƒqy2â€‹â‹¯Qiqâ€‹yiâ€‹:âŸ¨x,y1â€‹,y2â€‹,â‹¯,yiâ€‹âŸ©âˆˆLâ€²],

where QiQ_iQiâ€‹ is âˆƒ\existâˆƒ if iii is even, and âˆ€\forallâˆ€ if iii is odd.

Generalize whether P=NP,NP=coNPP=NP,NP=coNPP=NP,NP=coNP to question whether Î”iP=Î£iP,Î£iP=Î iP\Delta_i^P=\Sigma_i^P,\Sigma_i^P=\Pi_i^PÎ”iPâ€‹=Î£iPâ€‹,Î£iPâ€‹=Î iPâ€‹ for i>1i\gt1i>1.

ğŸ¯Theorem 29. If Î£iP=Î iP\Sigma_i^P=\Pi_i^PÎ£iPâ€‹=Î iPâ€‹ for some iâ‰¥1i\ge1iâ‰¥1 then PH=Î£iPPH=\Sigma_i^PPH=Î£iPâ€‹.

ç»§ç»­çœ‹ å¤©ä¹¦ã€‚

Completeness in the Polynomial-time Hierarchy

Î£iSAT\Sigma_iSATÎ£iâ€‹SAT Problem

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variables Ïˆ=âˆƒx1âˆ€x2â‹¯QixiÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xi)\psi=\exist x_1\forall x_2\cdots Q_ix_i\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_i)Ïˆ=âˆƒx1â€‹âˆ€x2â€‹â‹¯Qiâ€‹xiâ€‹Ï†(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xiâ€‹), where xjâˆˆ{0,1}njx_j\in\{0,1\}^{n_j}xjâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1}njâ€‹ for all jjj and Qi=âˆ€Q_i=\forallQiâ€‹=âˆ€ for even iii and âˆƒ\existâˆƒ for odd iii.

Question: Is Ïˆ\psiÏˆ true?

Î iSAT\Pi_iSATÎ iâ€‹SAT Problem

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variables Ïˆ=âˆ€x1âˆƒx2â‹¯QixiÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xi)\psi=\forall x_1\exist x_2\cdots Q_ix_i\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_i)Ïˆ=âˆ€x1â€‹âˆƒx2â€‹â‹¯Qiâ€‹xiâ€‹Ï†(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xiâ€‹), where xjâˆˆ{0,1}njx_j\in\{0,1\}^{n_j}xjâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1}njâ€‹ for all jjj and Qi=âˆ€Q_i=\forallQiâ€‹=âˆ€ for odd iii and âˆƒ\existâˆƒ for even iii.

Question: Is Ïˆ\psiÏˆ true?

ğŸ¯Theorem 30. Î£iSAT\Sigma_iSATÎ£iâ€‹SAT is complete for Î£iP\Sigma_i^PÎ£iPâ€‹ and Î iSAT\Pi_iSATÎ iâ€‹SAT is complete for Î iP\Pi_i^PÎ iPâ€‹.

å‰é¢çš„æ¨è®º 4 éƒ½æ²¡æ‡‚â€¦â€¦è¿™ä¸ªè¯æ˜å°±æ›´ä¸æ‡‚äº†

In case of Qi=âˆƒQ_i=\existQiâ€‹=âˆƒ, we ended up with a CNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ†.

In case of Qi=âˆ€Q_i=\forallQiâ€‹=âˆ€, we ended up with a DNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ†.

ğŸ¯Theorem 31. If PHPHPH has a complete language, then PHPHPH collapses.

This follows since PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE has complete problems.

Collapses åœ¨æ­¤å¤„æŒ‡å¤šé¡¹å¼å±‚æ¬¡ç»“æ„ä¸­æŸä¸€å±‚ä»¥ä¸Šçš„æ‰€æœ‰çº§åˆ«éƒ½é‡åˆçš„æƒ…å†µã€‚

The Karp-Lipton Theorem

A possible way to prove Pâ‰ NPP\neq NPPî€ =NP would be to show that there is some language in NPNPNP that is not computed by a family of polynomial size Boolean circuits, i.e., that NPâŠ†Ì¸P/polyNP\not\subseteq P/polyNPî€ âŠ†P/poly.

This is stronger than Pâ‰ NPP\neq NPPî€ =NP since PâŠ†P/polyP\subseteq P/polyPâŠ†P/poly. It turns out that it is not stronger than the assumption that the polynomial-time hierarchy does not collapse.

ğŸ¯Theorem 32. Suppose that NPâŠ†P/polyNP\subseteq P/polyNPâŠ†P/poly. Then PH=Î£2Pâˆ©Î 2PPH=\Sigma_2^P\cap\Pi_2^PPH=Î£2Pâ€‹âˆ©Î 2Pâ€‹.

Proof by Theorem 29, Corollary 4.

entry.summary:
Idea: arithmetic hierarchy from recursion theory.

Halting problem

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 4 Reductions and Completeness
entry.content:
Reductions

NP-completeness: by polynomial-time many-one reductions (aka Karp reductions)

Studying completeness of P and NL: by log-space many-one reduction. Also too powerful for completeness inside L.

ğŸ“–Definition 14 (Log-space reductions). Let L1âŠ†Î£1âˆ—L_1\subseteq\Sigma_1^*L1â€‹âŠ†Î£1âˆ—â€‹ and L2âŠ†Î£2âˆ—L_2\subseteq\Sigma_2^*L2â€‹âŠ†Î£2âˆ—â€‹ be languages. A log-space many-one reduction from L1L_1L1â€‹ to L2L_2L2â€‹ is a function f:Î£1âˆ—â†’Î£2âˆ—f:\Sigma_1^*\rarr\Sigma_2^*f:Î£1âˆ—â€‹â†’Î£2âˆ—â€‹ s.t.

  1. There exists a log-space Turing machine computing fff.
  2. For all xâˆˆÎ£1âˆ—x\in\Sigma_1^*xâˆˆÎ£1âˆ—â€‹, we have xâˆˆL1â‡”f(x)âˆˆL2x\in L_1\Lrarr f(x)\in L_2xâˆˆL1â€‹â‡”f(x)âˆˆL2â€‹.

Denote: L1â‰¤mlogâ¡L2L_1\le_m^{\log}L_2L1â€‹â‰¤mlogâ€‹L2â€‹

The definition of polynomial-time many-one reduction (L1â‰¤mpL2L_1\le_m^pL_2L1â€‹â‰¤mpâ€‹L2â€‹) is similar (simply using polynomial-time Turing machine instead).

ğŸ“–Definition 15 (â‰¤mlogâ¡\le_m^{\log}â‰¤mlogâ€‹-hard/complete). Let LLL be a language and C\mathcal CC be a class of languages. We say that LLL is â‰¤mlogâ¡\le_m^{\log}â‰¤mlogâ€‹-hard for C\mathcal CC if for every Lâ€²âˆˆCL'\in\mathcal CLâ€²âˆˆC we have Lâ€²â‰¤mlogâ¡LL'\le_m^{\log}LLâ€²â‰¤mlogâ€‹L. We say LLL is â‰¤mlogâ¡\le_m^{\log}â‰¤mlogâ€‹-complete if we additionally have LâˆˆCL\in\mathcal CLâˆˆC.

Reduction has property of transitivity.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 1. L1â‰¤mlogâ¡L2,L2â‰¤mlogâ¡L3â‡’L1â‰¤mlogâ¡L3L_1\le_m^{\log}L_2, L_2\le_m^{\log}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_m^{\log}L_3L1â€‹â‰¤mlogâ€‹L2â€‹,L2â€‹â‰¤mlogâ€‹L3â€‹â‡’L1â€‹â‰¤mlogâ€‹L3â€‹.

Let M1M_1M1â€‹ and M2M_2M2â€‹ be log-space Turing machines computing f1:L1â†’L2,f2:L2â†’L3f_1:L_1\to L_2,f_2:L_2\to L_3f1â€‹:L1â€‹â†’L2â€‹,f2â€‹:L2â€‹â†’L3â€‹, respectively. It suffices to show that f=f2âˆ˜f1f=f_2\circ f_1f=f2â€‹âˆ˜f1â€‹ is computable by log-space Turing machine MMM.

On input xxx, we simulate M2M_2M2â€‹ with virtual input tape f1(x)f_1(x)f1â€‹(x). We maintain a counter giving the position of the virtual input tape head of M2M_2M2â€‹. To simulate step of computation of M2M_2M2â€‹, we start simulating M1M_1M1â€‹ on input xxx, counting and then discarding the output symbols by M1M_1M1â€‹ until the output symbol where the virtual input tape head is placed is to be written. Then the step of M2M_2M2â€‹ can be complete.

Let xxx be of length n=âˆ£nâˆ£n=|n|n=âˆ£nâˆ£. âˆ£f(x)âˆ£=2O(logâ¡n)=nO(1)|f(x)|=2^{O(\log n)}=n^{O(1)}âˆ£f(x)âˆ£=2O(logn)=nO(1), storing the position of the virtual tape head as well as the work tapes of M1M_1M1â€‹ and M2M_2M2â€‹ takes space O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn).

æˆ‘è§‰å¾—ä¹ŸæŒºæ˜¾ç„¶çš„å‘€ï¼Œç”¨ä¸¤å°å¯¹æ•°ç©ºé—´çš„å›¾çµæœºæ¨¡æ‹Ÿï¼Œæ€»ç©ºé—´ä»ç„¶æ˜¯å¯¹æ•°çš„ã€‚

Then we define reduction âª¯\preceqâª¯ between languages.

ğŸ“–Definition 16. A language LLL is hard for C\mathcal CC under âª¯\preceqâª¯ reductions if for all Lâ€²âˆˆCL'\in\mathcal CLâ€²âˆˆC we have Lâ€²âª¯LL'\preceq LLâ€²âª¯L. A language LLL is complete for C\mathcal CC under âª¯\preceqâª¯ reductions if LâˆˆCL\in\mathcal CLâˆˆC in addition to begin hard for C\mathcal CC under âª¯\preceqâª¯ reductions.

Complexity class has an important property: the complexity class is closed under reductions.

We say C\mathcal CC is closed w.r.t. âª¯\preceqâª¯ reductions, if whenever Lâ€²âª¯LL'\preceq LLâ€²âª¯L and LâˆˆCL\in\mathcal CLâˆˆC, we also have Lâ€²âˆˆCL'\in CLâ€²âˆˆC. Proof omitted.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 2. The classes L,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPL,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPL,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXP are all closed under log-space many-one reductions. The classes P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPP,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPP,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXP are all closed under polynomial-time many-one reductions.

NL-completeness

The basic NL-complete problem is given by connectivity in a directed graph (STCONSTCONSTCON).

STCON

The instance: Directed graph DDD and nodes sss and ttt.

Question: Is there a directed path in DDD from sss to ttt?

ğŸ¯Theorem 20. STCONSTCONSTCON is complete for NL.

A non-deterministic log-space Turing machine can guess a path from sss to ttt one node at a time, reusing space.

To show NL-hardness, Let LâˆˆNLL\in NLLâˆˆNL be accepted by non-deterministic log-space Turing machine MMM.

Given input xxx s.t. MMM accepts xxx iff there is a path in the configuration graph of MMM on input xxx from the initial configuration to an accepting configuration.

A log-space reduction from LLL to STCONSTCONSTCON is:

On input xxx we generate all configurations of MMM on input xxx, which then forms the set of nodes together with an additional node ttt. Initial configuration becomes the node sss.

Next generate all arcs between configurations corresponding to a single step of the Turing machine and finally arcs between all accepting configurations to the new node ttt. We then have that the resulting directed graph DDD has a path from sss to ttt iff MMM accepts xxx.

By Savitchâ€™s Theorem and Immerman-SzelepcsÃ©nyi Theorem, STCONâˆˆDSPACE(logâ¡2n)STCON\in DSPACE(\log^2n)STCONâˆˆDSPACE(log2n) and STCONâ€¾âˆˆNL\overline{STCON}\in NLSTCONâˆˆNL, respectively.

P/NP-completeness

Basic PPP and NPNPNP-complete problems are given by the ability of Boolean circuits to simulate Turing machines on fixed input length. For PPP this gives the circuit value problem.

CVP problem

Instance: Boolean circuit CCC on nnn inputs and input xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n.

Question: Is C(x)=1C(x)=1C(x)=1?

ğŸ¯Theorem 21. CVPCVPCVP is complete for PPP.

SAT problem

CircuitSAT

Instance: Boolean circuit CCC on nnn inputs

Question: Does there exist xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n s.t. C(x)=1C(x)=1C(x)=1?

ğŸ¯Theorem 22. CircuitSATCircuitSATCircuitSAT is complete for NPNPNP.

Let me use Chinese

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆ CircuitSAT å±äº NPNPNPã€‚ç®€å•ç†è§£å°±æ˜¯éç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœº NTM å¯ä»¥åœ¨å¤šé¡¹å¼æ—¶é—´è§£å†³æ­¤é—®é¢˜ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„æ€æƒ³å°±æ˜¯æš´åŠ›æšä¸¾ï¼Œä¸€å…±éå† 2n2^n2n æ¬¡ã€‚è¿™æ ·åœ¨ç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœº DTM ä¸Šç¡®å®å°±æ˜¯ O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n)ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åœ¨éç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœºä¸Šï¼Œå°±å‰å®³äº†ã€‚é’ˆå¯¹æ¯ä¸€ä½ï¼Œéç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœºå¯ä»¥åŒæ—¶çŒœæµ‹ 000 å’Œ 111ï¼Œè¿™æ ·ä¸€å…±éå† nnn æ¬¡åˆ†åˆ«å¯¹åº” nnn ä½ï¼Œå°±å¾—åˆ°äº† NPNPNP çš„ç»“æœã€‚

As for NPNPNP-hard, construct language LâˆˆNTIME(nk)L\in NTIME(n^k)LâˆˆNTIME(nk) for k>0k\gt0k>0.

â€¦

SAT

Instance: CNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ†.

Question: Does Ï†\varphiÏ† have a satisfying assigment?

ğŸ¯Theorem 23. CNF satisfiability problem is also complete for NPNPNP.

Itâ€™s easy to see SATâˆˆNPSAT\in NPSATâˆˆNP.

For hardness, by reduction from CircuitSATCircuitSATCircuitSAT.

Given a Boolean circuit CCC, take Tseitin transformation of CCC giving an equi-satisfiable CNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ†.

This involves introducing new variable for each gate of CCC.

The number of new variable for each gate is a constant.

3SAT ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ NP çš„ï¼Œå³æ¯ä¸ªåˆå–èŒƒå¼æœ€å¤šåŒ…å«ä¸‰ä¸ªå­å¥ã€‚

PSPACE-completeness

Basic PSPACE-completeness is given by the problem of deciding validity of true quantified Boolean formulas as shown by Stockmeyer and Meyer. (TQBFTQBFTQBF)

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variable Ïˆ=Q1x1Q2x2â‹¯QnxnÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)\psi=Q_1x_1Q_2x_2\cdots Q_nx_n\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)Ïˆ=Q1â€‹x1â€‹Q2â€‹x2â€‹â‹¯Qnâ€‹xnâ€‹Ï†(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹), where Qiâˆˆ{âˆ€,âˆƒ}Q_i\in\{\forall,\exist\}Qiâ€‹âˆˆ{âˆ€,âˆƒ} and xiâˆˆ{0,1}x_i\in\{0,1\}xiâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1} for all iii.

Question: Is Ïˆ\psiÏˆ true?

ğŸ¯Theorem 24. TQBFTQBFTQBF is complete for PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE.

To see TQBFâˆˆPSPACETQBF\in PSPACETQBFâˆˆPSPACE: The algorithm is a recursion. At the bottom of the recursion, if Qi=âˆ€Q_i=\forallQiâ€‹=âˆ€, return 111 iff both returned 111; if Qi=âˆƒQ_i=\existQiâ€‹=âˆƒ, return 000 iff both returned 000. We of course need a stack with length O(n)O(n)O(n) for evaluating Ï†\varphiÏ†.

To show hardness, proof similar to Savitchâ€™s theorem.

â€¦

EXP/NEXP-completeness

Consider so-called succinct versions of complete problems of PPP and NPNPNP.

Let CCC be a Boolean circuit with nnn input gates and one output gate. The truthtable of CCC is the string tt(C)âˆˆ{0,1}2ntt(C)\in\{0,1\}^{2^n}tt(C)âˆˆ{0,1}2n giving the evaluation of CCC on all possible inputs.

Consider a language LâŠ†{0,1}âˆ—L\subseteq\{0,1\}^*LâŠ†{0,1}âˆ—. Then define the succinct version SuccinctLSuccinctLSuccinctL of LLL simply by SuccinctL={Câˆ£tt(C)âˆˆL}SuccinctL=\{C|tt(C)\in L\}SuccinctL={Câˆ£tt(C)âˆˆL}. Note that when LâˆˆPL\in PLâˆˆP we have that SuccinctLâˆˆEXPSuccinctL\in EXPSuccinctLâˆˆEXP simply by decompressing the input CCC to tt(C)tt(C)tt(C) in exponential time and then using the polynomial-time Turing machine to check for membership in LLL.

ç®€è€Œè¨€ä¹‹ï¼ŒæŠŠä¸Šé¢è¿™äº›ç©æ„çš„çœŸå€¼è¡¨ç®—å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯å±äº EXP/NEXP çš„å¤æ‚åº¦ç±»ã€‚

Similarly we have SuccinctLâˆˆNEXPSuccinctL\in NEXPSuccinctLâˆˆNEXP when LâˆˆNPL\in NPLâˆˆNP.

ğŸ¯Theorem 25. SuccinctCVPSuccinctCVPSuccinctCVP is complete for EXPEXPEXP.

Similar transformation.

ğŸ¯Theorem 26. SucinctCircuitSATSucinctCircuitSATSucinctCircuitSAT and SuccinctSATSuccinctSATSuccinctSAT are complete for NEXPNEXPNEXP.

Die meisten von uns sind vor und in PrÃ¼fungssituationen aufgeregt, haben feuchte HÃ¤nde oder gehen stÃ¤ndig auf die Toilette. æ‰‹å¿ƒå†’æ±—æˆ–è€…ç»å¸¸ä¸Šå•æ‰€ Starke PrÃ¼fungsangst blockiert uns oder macht uns vielleicht sogar in Form eines Blackout denk- und handlungsunfÃ¤hig. ä¸¥é‡çš„è€ƒè¯•ç„¦è™‘ä¼šé˜»ç¢æˆ‘ä»¬æˆ–è®©å¤§è„‘çŸ­è·¯ï¼Œç”šè‡³å¯èƒ½ä½¿æˆ‘ä»¬æ— æ³•æ€è€ƒæˆ–è¡ŒåŠ¨ã€‚

Zweiten muss man wissen, warum er PrÃ¼fungsangst hat. Ich hatte PrÃ¼fungsangst, weil ich von meinen Eltern hÃ¤ufig Ã¼berfordert wurden. Noch ein wichtiger Punkt ist: Immer daran denken, dass es noch etwas Schlimmeres gibt! Sollen du durch die PrÃ¼fung fallen, geht davon die Welt auch nicht unter.

AuÃŸerdem soll man natÃ¼rlich rechtzeitig mit der Vorbereitung anfangen. Eine richtige, individuell passende Lernmethode und eine richtige Zeiteinteilung sorgen fÃ¼r eine optimale Vorbereitung.

Dann soll man die PrÃ¼fungssituation immer wieder Ã¼ben. Vergiss bitte nicht, ausreichend zu schlafen!

Ich hoffe, dass meine Tipps dir helfen wÃ¼rden. Ich glaube, dass du deine AbschlussprÃ¼fung locker schaffst!

Und natÃ¼rlich mÃ¶chte ich mit dir und Isabella zusammen deinen Abschluss feiern. FÃ¼r dich habe ich immer Zeit. Wenn du mit allen PrÃ¼fungen fertig bist, kÃ¶nnen wir uns dann treffen.

Ich wÃ¼nsche dir dann viel Erfolg bei den AbschlussprÃ¼fungen!

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 3 Boolean Circuits
entry.content:
Non-uniform model of computation: Boolean circuit model.

In contrast to uniform model like Turing machine.

Boolean circuit: Fixed number of inputs. To study computation of arbitrary inputs, we need a family of Boolean circuits.

Some Definitions

ğŸ“–Definition of Boolean circuit. A Boolean circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of:

  1. A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) where the in-degree of every node is at most 222.
  2. A labeling â„“\ellâ„“ of all nodes gâˆˆVg\in VgâˆˆV with \ell(g)\in\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n,\overline{x_1},\cdots,\overline{x_n},\and,\or, eg\}.
  3. A choice of mmm output gates o1,â‹¯â€‰,omâˆˆVo_1,\cdots, o_m\in Vo1â€‹,â‹¯,omâ€‹âˆˆV.

The nodes of DDD is the gates of CCC, the arcs of DDD is the wires of CCC.

Nodes with in-degree 000 are input gates.

The size of CCC is the number of gates.

Fanin of a gate is its in-degree, fanout is its out-degree.

Labeling function should satisfy: For all gates ggg:

  1. If the fanin is 000, then \ell(g)\in\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n,\overline{x_1},\cdots,\overline{x_n},\and,\or, eg\}.
  2. If the fanin is 111, then â„“(g)=Â¬\ell(g)= egâ„“(g)=Â¬.
  3. If the fanin is 222, then \ell(g)\in\{\and,\or\}.

A Boolean circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs computes a Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}mf:\{0,1\}^n o\{0,1\}^mf:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}m.

Implicit negation such as xiâ€¾\overline{x_i}xiâ€‹â€‹ can be made explicit by introducing a new gate, thereby at most doubling the size of the circuit.

ğŸ“–Definition of family of Boolean circuits. A family (Cn)n=0âˆ(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cnâ€‹)n=0âˆâ€‹ of Boolean circuits, where CnC_nCnâ€‹ is a circuit with nnn inputs computes the Boolean function f:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^* o\{0,1\}f:{0,1}âˆ—â†’{0,1} given by f(x)=Câˆ£xâˆ£(x)f(x)=C_{|x|}(x)f(x)=Câˆ£xâˆ£â€‹(x). We say that (Cn)n=0âˆ(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cnâ€‹)n=0âˆâ€‹ computes the language LâŠ†{0,1}â‹†L\subseteq\{0,1\}^\starLâŠ†{0,1}â‹† if (Cn)n=0âˆ(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cnâ€‹)n=0âˆâ€‹ computes the characteristic function Ï‡L:{0,1}â‹†â†’{0,1}\chi_L:\{0,1\}^\star o\{0,1\}Ï‡Lâ€‹:{0,1}â‹†â†’{0,1} of LLL given by Ï‡L(x)=1\chi_L(x)=1Ï‡Lâ€‹(x)=1 iff xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL.

ç›´ç™½ä¸€ç‚¹ï¼šæˆ‘ä»¬è¯´ä¸€ä¸ªå¸ƒå°”ç”µè·¯æ— (Cn)n=0âˆ(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cnâ€‹)n=0âˆâ€‹ è®¡ç®—~~ï¼ˆæ¥å—ï¼Ÿï¼‰~~è¯­è¨€ LLLï¼Œå½“ä¸”ä»…å½“è¯¥å¸ƒå°”ç”µè·¯æ—çš„è¾“å…¥ xxx å±äºè¯­è¨€ LLLæ—¶ï¼Œè¾“å‡ºç»“æœä¸º 111ã€‚

If we want to apply non-Boolean alphabet, we just encode these letters into {0,1}k\{0,1\}^k{0,1}k for some fixed kkk.

ğŸ“–Definition of SIZESIZESIZE. Let S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N o\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N. SIZE(S(n))SIZE(S(n))SIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by family of Boolean circuit of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)),

We interested in class of languages computed by a family of polynomial size.

P/poly=â‹ƒk>0SIZE(nk).P/poly= igcup_{k>0}SIZE(n^k).P/poly=k>0â‹ƒâ€‹SIZE(nk).

ğŸ“–Definition of log-space/polynomial-time uniform. Let (Cn)n=0âˆ(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cnâ€‹)n=0âˆâ€‹ be a family of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)). We say that the family is log-space uniform if the function 1nâ†¦Cn1^n\mapsto C_n1nâ†¦Cnâ€‹ is computable in space O(logâ¡S(n))O(\log S(n))O(logS(n)). The family is polynomial-time uniform if the function is computable in time (S(n))O(1)(S(n))^{O(1)}(S(n))O(1).

ğŸ“–Definition of complexity classes of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits. Let S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N o\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N.

  • ULâˆ’SIZE(S(n))U_L-SIZE(S(n))ULâ€‹âˆ’SIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by log-space uniform families of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)).
  • UPâˆ’SIZE(S(n))U_P-SIZE(S(n))UPâ€‹âˆ’SIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by polynomial-time uniform families of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)).

Boolean Formulas

ğŸ“–Definition of Boolean formulas. A Boolean formula (aka de Morgan formula) is a Boolean circuit where the underlying directed graph is a tree.

åˆå–èŒƒå¼ conjunctive normal form CNF

æå–èŒƒå¼ disjunctive normal form DNF

ğŸ¯Theorem 14. Any Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n o\{0,1\}f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1} is computed by a CNF with sss clauses of length nnn and a DNF with ttt terms of length nnn where

s=âˆ£{xâˆˆ{0,1}nâˆ£f(x)=0}âˆ£,t=âˆ£{xâˆˆ{0,1}nâˆ£f(x)=1}âˆ£.s=|\{x\in\{0,1\}^n|f(x)=0\}|,\t=|\{x\in\{0,1\}^n|f(x)=1\}|.s=âˆ£{xâˆˆ{0,1}nâˆ£f(x)=0}âˆ£,t=âˆ£{xâˆˆ{0,1}nâˆ£f(x)=1}âˆ£.

The Shannon Function

The smallest size L(n)L(n)L(n) in which any Boolean function on nnn variables can be computed by a Boolean circuit of size L(n)L(n)L(n).

The function L(n)L(n)L(n) is called the Shannon function.

By DNF/CNF formulas, we have trivial bound L(n)â‰¤n2nL(n)\le n2^nL(n)â‰¤n2n.

Shannon proved that L(n)=Î˜(2n/n)L(n)=\Theta(2^n/n)L(n)=Î˜(2n/n).

ğŸ¯Theorem 15 (Lower Bound on Circuit Size). L(n)>2n4nL(n)> rac{2^n}{4n}L(n)>4n2nâ€‹ for nâ‰¥9n\ge9nâ‰¥9. In fact, the fraction of Boolean functions computed by Boolean circuits of size at most 2n4n rac{2^n}{4n}4n2nâ€‹ is at most 2âˆ’2nâˆ’12^{-2^{n-1}}2âˆ’2nâˆ’1 for nâ‰¥9n\ge9nâ‰¥9.

For a given number of inputs nâ‰¥1n\ge1nâ‰¥1: first give an upper bound on number of Boolean circuits with nnn inputs and 111 output, with at most sâ‰¥1s\ge1sâ‰¥1 gates. Consider an acyclic ordering of the gates of the circuit and assume the last gate is the output gate.

Different types of gate: input gates have 2n+22n+22n+2 probabilities, negation with one input sss, and/or with two inputs (s2,s2)(s^2,s^2)(s2,s2). Thus we have at most 2n+2+s+s2+s22n+2+s+s^2+s^22n+2+s+s2+s2 options for every gate, meaning that we have at most (2n+2+s+2s2)s(2n+2+s+2s^2)^s(2n+2+s+2s2)s many circuits with at most sss gates.

For sâ‰¥n+1s\ge n+1sâ‰¥n+1 we have

2n+2+s+2s2â‰¤4s2â‡’(2n+2+s+2s2)sâ‰¤(2s)2s.2n+2+s+2s^2\le4s^2\\Rarr(2n+2+s+2s^2)^s\le(2s)^{2s}.2n+2+s+2s2â‰¤4s2â‡’(2n+2+s+2s2)sâ‰¤(2s)2s.

Each of these at most (2s)2s(2s)^{2s}(2s)2s circuits computes precisely one Boolean function. There are exactly 22n2^{2^n}22n different Boolean functions on nnn inputs.

Thus if 22n>(2s)2s2^{2^n}\gt(2s)^{2s}22n>(2s)2s, there must be a Boolean function that is not computed by a Boolean circuit of size sss. (By pigeon hole theorem)

Let nâ‰¥9,s=2n4nn\ge9,s= rac{2^n}{4n}nâ‰¥9,s=4n2nâ€‹, which satisfies sâ‰¥n+1s\ge n+1sâ‰¥n+1, we have

(2s)2s=22slogâ¡2(2s)=22n2n(nâˆ’1âˆ’logâ¡n)<22nâˆ’1.(2s)^{2s}=2^{2s\log_2(2s)}=2^{ rac{2^n}{2n}(n-1-\log n)}\lt2^{2^{n-1}}.(2s)2s=22slog2â€‹(2s)=22n2nâ€‹(nâˆ’1âˆ’logn)<22nâˆ’1.

It follows that less than 22nâˆ’12^{2^{n-1}}22nâˆ’1 Boolean functions on nnn inputs are computed by Boolean circuits of size at most 2n4n rac{2^n}{4n}4n2nâ€‹.

Turing Machines versus Boolean Circuits

Oblivious Turing machine can efficiently be converted to a family of Boolean circuits.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 1. Let T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n and suppose LLL is computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded oblivious Turing machine. Then LâˆˆSIZE(T(n))L\in SIZE(T(n))LâˆˆSIZE(T(n)).

Any configuration of oblivious Turing machine on input xxx can be encoded by a binary string of length O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) s.t. every symbol of every work tape corresponds to a fixed number of positions of the encoding.

We can build the Boolean circuit for input length nnn in O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) steps. Proof by induction.

Proposition 1 and Theorem 4 result in some inclusion relation.

ğŸ¯Theorem 16. DTIME(T(n))âŠ†SIZE(T(n)logâ¡T(n))DTIME(T(n))\subseteq SIZE(T(n)\log T(n))DTIME(T(n))âŠ†SIZE(T(n)logT(n)) for T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n.

Turing machine is supplied with an advice string in addition to the input, where the advice string is specific to the input length.

ğŸ“–Definition of Advice classes. Let C\mathcal CC be a class of languages and f:Nâ†’Nf:\mathbb N o\mathbb Nf:Nâ†’N a function. Define C/f(n)\mathcal C/f(n)C/f(n) to be the class of languages LLL for which there exist Lâ€²âˆˆCL'\in\mathcal CLâ€²âˆˆC satisfying that for all input lengths nnn, there is an advice string yny_nynâ€‹ of length f(n)f(n)f(n) s.t. for all xxx of length nnn, we have xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL iff âŸ¨x,ynâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²\langle x,y_n angle\in L'âŸ¨x,ynâ€‹âŸ©âˆˆLâ€². For a family F\mathcal FF of functions F:Nâ†’NF:\mathbb N o\mathbb NF:Nâ†’N, we let C/F=â‹ƒfâˆˆFC/f(n)\mathcal C/\mathcal F= igcup_{f\in\mathcal F}\mathcal C/f(n)C/F=â‹ƒfâˆˆFâ€‹C/f(n).

ğŸ¯Theorem 17. Let S(n)â‰¥nS(n)\ge nS(n)â‰¥n. Then SIZE(S(n))âŠ†DTIME(S(n)2)/O(S(n)logâ¡S(n))SIZE(S(n))\subseteq DTIME(S(n)^2)/O(S(n)\log S(n))SIZE(S(n))âŠ†DTIME(S(n)2)/O(S(n)logS(n)).

The advice string (length nnn) is an encoding of the circuit CnC_nCnâ€‹, which is a string of length O(S(n)logâ¡S(n))O(S(n)\log S(n))O(S(n)logS(n)).

Assume that the gates of CnC_nCnâ€‹ are given in the encoding in acyclic order. On input xxx of length nnn and advice CnC_nCnâ€‹, a Turing machine can evaluate CnC_nCnâ€‹ on input xxx, evaluating the gates in the given acyclic ordering and storing all intermediate outputs.

To evaluate each gate we need to retrieve the computed value of its inputs, which will take O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) time. Doing this for all O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) gates leads to O(S(n)2)O(S(n)^2)O(S(n)2).

ğŸ¯Corollary 1. Let T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n. Then DTIME(T(n)O(1))/T(n)O(1)=SIZE(T(n)O(1))DTIME(T(n)^{O(1)})/T(n)^{O(1)}=SIZE(T(n)^{O(1)})DTIME(T(n)O(1))/T(n)O(1)=SIZE(T(n)O(1))

Proof by Definition of advice class and Theorem 17.

ğŸ¯Theorem 18. Let T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n and suppose the function 1nâ†¦T(n)1^n\mapsto T(n)1nâ†¦T(n) is computable in space O(logâ¡T(n))O(\log T(n))O(logT(n)). Then DTIME(T(n))âŠ†ULâˆ’SIZE(T(n)logâ¡T(n))DTIME(T(n))\subseteq U_L-SIZE(T(n)\log T(n))DTIME(T(n))âŠ†ULâ€‹âˆ’SIZE(T(n)logT(n)).

ğŸ¯Theorem 19. Let (S(n))â‰¥n(S(n))\ge n(S(n))â‰¥n. Then ULâˆ’SIZE(S(n))âŠ†DTIME(S(n)O(1))U_L-SIZE(S(n))\subseteq DTIME(S(n)^{O(1)})ULâ€‹âˆ’SIZE(S(n))âŠ†DTIME(S(n)O(1)).

ğŸ¯Corollary 2. Let T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n and suppose that function 1nâ†¦T(n)1^n\mapsto T(n)1nâ†¦T(n) is computable in space O(logâ¡T(n))O(\log T(n))O(logT(n)). Then DTIME(T(n)O(1))=ULâˆ’SIZE(T(n)O(1))DTIME(T(n)^{O(1)})=U_L-SIZE(T(n)^{O(1)})DTIME(T(n)O(1))=ULâ€‹âˆ’SIZE(T(n)O(1)).

In particular, we have P=ULâˆ’SIZE(nO(1))P=U_L-SIZE(n^{O(1)})P=ULâ€‹âˆ’SIZE(nO(1)).
entry.summary:
Non-uniform model of computation: Boolean circuit model.

In contrast to uniform model like Turing machine.

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 2 Nondeterminism and Determinism
entry.content:
The sequence of transitions is called computation history.

Non-deterministic Turing machine will crush also when there is no possible next step according to the transition relation.

Non-deterministic Time and Space Complexity

Worst-case definition of time and space to solve a issue by non-deterministic Turing machine.

Let MMM be a non-deterministic Turing machine. For given input xâˆˆÎ£âˆ—x\in\Sigma^*xâˆˆÎ£âˆ—,

  • timeM(x)time_M(x)timeMâ€‹(x) is the maximum number of computation steps that MMM performs on input xxx until halting.
  • spaceM(x)space_M(x)spaceMâ€‹(x) is the maximum number of cell on work tapes that are some point scanned by a tape head during computation.

ğŸ“–Definition of non-deterministic complexity classes:

Let T:Nâ†’NT:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NT:Nâ†’N and S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N\rarr NS:Nâ†’N be functions with T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n.

NTIME(T(n))NTIME(T(n))NTIME(T(n)) is the class of languages computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine.

NSPACE(T(n))NSPACE(T(n))NSPACE(T(n)) is the class of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine.

Non-deterministic Hierarchy Theorems

ğŸ¯Theorem 7 (Non-deterministic Space Hierarchy Theorem). Let S2(n)â‰¥logâ¡nS_2(n)\ge\log nS2â€‹(n)â‰¥logn be space constructible. If S1(n)=o(S2(n))S_1(n)=o(S_2(n))S1â€‹(n)=o(S2â€‹(n)), then

NSPACE(S1(n))âŠŠNSPACE(S2(n)).NSPACE(S_1(n))\subsetneq NSPACE(S_2(n)).NSPACE(S1â€‹(n))âŠŠNSPACE(S2â€‹(n)).

å’Œ ä¸Šä¸€è¯¾ çš„å®šç† 3 ä¸€æ ·ã€‚å­˜å‚¨ç©ºé—´è¶Šå¤šï¼Œâ€œè¯†åˆ«çš„è¯­è¨€â€ä¹Ÿå°±è¶Šå¤šã€‚

Proof by Immermanâ€“SzelepcsÃ©nyi theorem.

For non-deterministic time: rely on technique â€œdelayed diagonalizationâ€. å»¶è¿Ÿå¯¹è§’åŒ–

ğŸ¯Theorem 8 (Time-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine). Let T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n and suppose MMM is a T(n)T(n)T(n) time-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine with kkk work tapes. Then there exists a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine with 222 work tapes s.t. L(M)=L(Mâ€²)L(M)=L(M')L(M)=L(Mâ€²).

ğŸ¯Theorem 9 (Non-deterministic Time Hierarchy Theorem). Let T2(n)â‰¥nT_2(n)\ge nT2â€‹(n)â‰¥n be time constructible and non-decreasing. If T1(n)T_1(n)T1â€‹(n) satisfies T1(n+1)=o(T2(n))T_1(n+1)=o(T_2(n))T1â€‹(n+1)=o(T2â€‹(n)), then

NTIME(T1(n))âŠŠNTIME(T2(n))NTIME(T_1(n))\subsetneq NTIME(T_2(n))NTIME(T1â€‹(n))âŠŠNTIME(T2â€‹(n))

èŠ±çš„æ—¶é—´è¶Šé•¿ï¼Œè§£å†³é—®é¢˜å°±è¶Šå¤šã€‚

Proof by constructing MMM s.t. L(M)âˆˆÌ¸NTIME(T1(n))L(M)\not\in NTIME(T_1(n))L(M)î€ âˆˆNTIME(T1â€‹(n)).

Relating Deterministic and Non-deterministic Computation

ğŸ¯Theorem 10. Let T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n. Then NTIME(T(n))âŠ†DSPACE(T(n))NTIME(T(n))\subseteq DSPACE(T(n))NTIME(T(n))âŠ†DSPACE(T(n)).

ğŸ¯Theorem 11. Let S(n)â‰¥logâ¡nS(n)\ge\log nS(n)â‰¥logn. Then NSPACE(S(n))âŠ†DTIME(2O(S(n)))NSPACE(S(n))\subseteq DTIME(2^{O(S(n))})NSPACE(S(n))âŠ†DTIME(2O(S(n))).

Savitchâ€™s Theorem

Better than NSPACE(S(n))âŠ†DSPACE(2O(S(n)))NSPACE(S(n))\subseteq DSPACE(2^{O(S(n))})NSPACE(S(n))âŠ†DSPACE(2O(S(n))).

ğŸ¯Theorem 12 (Savitchâ€™s Theorem). Let S(n)â‰¥logâ¡nS(n)\ge\log nS(n)â‰¥logn. Then

NSPACE(S(n))âŠ†DSPACE(S(n)2).NSPACE(S(n))\subseteq DSPACE(S(n)^2).NSPACE(S(n))âŠ†DSPACE(S(n)2).

Hard proof

The Immermanâ€“SzelepcsÃ©nyi Theorem

Non-deterministic space is closed under the operation of taking complements.

coNSPACE(S(n))coNSPACE(S(n))coNSPACE(S(n)): The class of complement languages of languages in NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n)).

ğŸ¯Theorem 13 (Immermanâ€“SzelepcsÃ©nyi theorem). Let S(n)â‰¥logâ¡nS(n)\ge\log nS(n)â‰¥logn. Then

coNSPACE(S(n))=NSPACE(S(n)).coNSPACE(S(n))=NSPACE(S(n)).coNSPACE(S(n))=NSPACE(S(n)).

Non-deterministic Time and Space Complexity Classes

NL=NSPACE(logâ¡n)NP=â‹ƒk>0NTIME(nk)NEXP=â‹ƒk>0NTIME(2nk)NL=NSPACE(\log n)\\NP=\bigcup_{k\gt0}NTIME(n^k)\\NEXP=\bigcup_{k\gt0}NTIME(2^{n^k})NL=NSPACE(logn)NP=k>0â‹ƒâ€‹NTIME(nk)NEXP=k>0â‹ƒâ€‹NTIME(2nk)

Relations:

  • Due to Savitchâ€™s theorem, there is no need for defining NSPACENSPACENSPACE.

  • NLâŠ†NPâŠ†PSPACEâŠ†NEXPNL\subseteq NP\subseteq PSPACE\subseteq NEXPNLâŠ†NPâŠ†PSPACEâŠ†NEXP.

  • By non-deterministic time and space hierarchy theorems: NLâŠŠPSPACENL\subsetneq PSPACENLâŠŠPSPACE, NPâŠŠNEXPNP\subsetneq NEXPNPâŠŠNEXP.

Thus, LâŠ†NLâŠ†PâŠ†NPâŠ†PSPACEâŠ†EXPâŠ†NEXPL\subseteq NL\subseteq P\subseteq NP\subseteq PSPACE\subseteq EXP\subseteq NEXPLâŠ†NLâŠ†PâŠ†NPâŠ†PSPACEâŠ†EXPâŠ†NEXP.

Summary of Complexity Classes

  1. L (Logarithmic Space)
    • Definition: LLL consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine using O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn) space.
    • Example: Determining if a path exists between two nodes in an undirected graph using depth-first search with a space-efficient representation.
  2. NL (Non-deterministic Logarithmic Space)
    • Definition: NLNLNL consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a non-deterministic Turing machine using O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn) space.
    • Example: Determining if a path exists between two nodes in a directed graph (also known as the reachability problem).
  3. P (Polynomial Time)
    • Definition: PPP consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine in polynomial time, O(nk)O(n^k)O(nk) for some constant kkk.
    • Example: Sorting an array using algorithms like Merge Sort or Quick Sort.
  4. NP (Non-deterministic Polynomial Time)
    • Definition: NPNPNP consists of all decision problems for which a given solution can be verified in polynomial time by a deterministic Turing machine. Equivalently, problems solvable by a non-deterministic Turing machine in polynomial time.
    • Example: The Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT).
  5. PSPACE (Polynomial Space)
    • Definition: PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine using polynomial space.
    • Example: Generalized games like chess, checkers, and go with a polynomial bound on the number of moves.
  6. EXP (Exponential Time)
    • Definition: EXPEXPEXP consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine in exponential time, O(2p(n))O(2^{p(n)})O(2p(n)) for some polynomial p(n)p(n)p(n).
    • Example: Solving the traveling salesman problem using a brute-force search over all possible paths.
  7. NEXP (Non-deterministic Exponential Time)
    • Definition: NEXPNEXPNEXP consists of all decision problems solvable by a non-deterministic Turing machine in exponential time, O(2p(n))O(2^{p(n)})O(2p(n)) for some polynomial p(n)p(n)p(n).
    • Example: Certain advanced combinatorial problems that require guessing an exponentially long solution and verifying it in exponential time.

We donâ€™t know whether these inclusions are strict. But we usually assume that all the inclusions are strict.

P=NPP=NPP=NP implies EXP=NEXPEXP=NEXPEXP=NEXP; EXPâ‰ NEXPEXP\neq NEXPEXPî€ =NEXP implies Pâ‰ NPP\neq NPPî€ =NP.
