entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 1 Turing Machines, Time and Space
entry.content:
Theory of Algorithms and Computational Complexity

Lecturer: Kristoffer Arnsfelt Hansen

â˜ ï¸â˜ ï¸â˜ ï¸The most difficult (no â€œone ofâ€) course in my masterâ€™s study.â˜ ï¸â˜ ï¸â˜ ï¸

Brief Intro to TACC

Study of efficient computation

1960s Hartmanis, Stearns - Time Hierarchy Theorem.

Turing machine, register based machine can simulate each other.

Turing Machines

Turing machines - simple, and has some nice properties:

  • Clean definition of complexity (time and space)
  • Straightforward to non-determinism and randomness.

Consider â€œoffline multi-tape sequential Turing machineâ€

Turing machine is a finite-state machine that can access and modify chars written on â€œtapesâ€ according to some rules.

Formal Definition

Turing machine MMM with one input tape and kkk work tapes. It includes:

  • Finite set QQQ: set of states

    • Element sâˆˆQs\in QsâˆˆQ: start state
    • Element yesâˆˆQyes\in QyesâˆˆQ: accept state
    • Element noâˆˆQno\in QnoâˆˆQ: reject state

  • Finite set Î“\GammaÎ“: the tape alphabet

    • non-empty finite set Î£âŠ†Î“\Sigma\subseteq\GammaÎ£âŠ†Î“: input alphabet

  • Element Î”âˆˆÎ“â•²Î£\Delta\in\Gamma\diagdown\SigmaÎ”âˆˆÎ“â•²Î£: blank symbol

  • Function

    Î´:(Qâ•²{yes,no})Ã—(Î£âˆª{Î”})Ã—Î“kâ†’QÃ—(Î“â•²{Î”})kÃ—{L,S,R}k+1\delta:(Q\diagdown\{yes,no\})\times(\Sigma\cup\{\Delta\})\times\Gamma^k\rarr Q\times(\Gamma\diagdown\{\Delta\})^k\times\{L,S,R\}^{k+1}Î´:(Qâ•²{yes,no})Ã—(Î£âˆª{Î”})Ã—Î“kâ†’QÃ—(Î“â•²{Î”})kÃ—{L,S,R}k+1

    is the transition function.

çŠ¶æ€è½¬ç§»æ–¹ç¨‹çš„æ„æ€ï¼š

è½¬ç§»å‰ï¼š(Qâ•²{yes,no})(Q\diagdown\{yes,no\})(Qâ•²{yes,no}) ä»£è¡¨è½¬ç§»å‰çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œä¸èƒ½æ˜¯æ¥å—æˆ–æ‹’ç»æ€ï¼ˆå› ä¸ºæ¥å—æˆ–æ‹’ç»å°±åœæœºäº†ï¼‰ï¼›(Î£âˆª{Î”})(\Sigma\cup\{\Delta\})(Î£âˆª{Î”}) ä»£è¡¨è¾“å…¥å­—ç¬¦ï¼›Î“k\Gamma^kÎ“k ä»£è¡¨ä¹‹å‰å½“å‰é’ˆå¤´åˆ†åˆ«æŒ‡ kkk ä¸ªå·¥ä½œçº¸å¸¦å¯¹åº”ä½ç½®çš„å­—ç¬¦ã€‚

è½¬ç§»åï¼šQQQ ä»£è¡¨è½¬ç§»åçš„çŠ¶æ€ï¼Œå¯ä»¥æ˜¯æ¥å—æˆ–æ‹’ç»æ€ï¼›(Î“â•²{Î”})k(\Gamma\diagdown\{\Delta\})^k(Î“â•²{Î”})k è¡¨ç¤ºé’ˆå¤´åˆ†åˆ«åœ¨ kkk ä¸ªå·¥ä½œçº¸å¸¦ä¸Šå¯¹åº”ä½ç½®å†™å…¥çš„å­—ç¬¦ï¼›{L,S,R}k+1\{L,S,R\}^{k+1}{L,S,R}k+1 è¡¨ç¤ºæ¥ä¸‹äº†è¾“å…¥çº¸å¸¦å’Œ kkk ä¸ªå·¥ä½œçº¸å¸¦åº”è¯¥å·¦ç§»ï¼ˆLLLï¼‰ã€å³ç§»ï¼ˆRRRï¼‰ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯ä¸åŠ¨ï¼ˆSSSï¼‰ã€‚

Transition Function has following properties:

  1. MMM will stop operation when entering yesyesyes or nonono state.
  2. MMM marks all cells visited on its work tapes

The operation of MMM:

  • k+1k+1k+1 two-way infinite tapes. One for input, the rest for work.
  • The cells of each work tape are numbered by the set Z\mathbb ZZ.
  • Input tape on which the cell 1,â‹¯â€‰,âˆ£xâˆ£1,\cdots,|x|1,â‹¯,âˆ£xâˆ£ are filled with char xix_ixiâ€‹. The other cells are filled with Î”\DeltaÎ”.
  • Each tape has a tape head, which initially stays at position 000.
  • The machine MMM maintain an element of AAA as its internal state.

The computation of MMM:

  • Move the tapes according to transition function
  • If input head is called to â€œmove leftâ€ at position 000, or â€œmove rightâ€ at position âˆ£xâˆ£+1|x|+1âˆ£xâˆ£+1, let MMM â€œcrashâ€. (So there are âˆ£xâˆ£+2|x|+2âˆ£xâˆ£+2 legal cell for input tape head)
  • When MMM enters yesyesyes or nonono, it stops. We called MMM halts. (M(x)=yesM(x)=yesM(x)=yes or M(x)=noM(x)=noM(x)=no)

Turing machine can be seen as language acceptor useful for decision problems whether the language is formal language, i.e., the language computed by MMM is L(M)={xâˆˆÎ£âˆ£M(x)="yes"}L(M)=\{x\in\Sigma|M(x)="yes"\}L(M)={xâˆˆÎ£âˆ£M(x)="yes"}.

An Extension on Turing Machine

Add an additional output tape which is write-only.

Î›\LambdaÎ›: non-empty finite set, output alphabet. (Usually Î›=Î£\Lambda=\SigmaÎ›=Î£)

In each step of computation MMM can choose to write a single symbol to the output tape. Then transition function:

Î´:(Qâ•²{yes,no})Ã—(Î£âˆª{Î”})Ã—Î“kâ†’QÃ—(Î“â•²{Î”})kÃ—(Î›âˆª{Ïµ})Ã—{L,S,R}k+1\delta:(Q\diagdown\{yes,no\})\times(\Sigma\cup\{\Delta\})\times\Gamma^k\\\rarr Q\times(\Gamma\diagdown\{\Delta\})^k\times(\Lambda\cup\{\epsilon\})\times\{L,S,R\}^{k+1}Î´:(Qâ•²{yes,no})Ã—(Î£âˆª{Î”})Ã—Î“kâ†’QÃ—(Î“â•²{Î”})kÃ—(Î›âˆª{Ïµ})Ã—{L,S,R}k+1

Ïµ\epsilonÏµ here means write nothing.

Such a Turing machine is also called a transducer.

Time and Space Complexity

For a given input xâˆˆÎ£âˆ—x\in\Sigma^*xâˆˆÎ£âˆ—:

  • timeM(x)time_M(x)timeMâ€‹(x) is the number of computational steps that MMM performs on input xxx until halting.
  • spaceM(x)space_M(x)spaceMâ€‹(x) is the total number of cells on the work tapes that are at some point scanned by a tape head during computation on input xxx.

Both time and space can be infinite. Space can be infinite when MMM does not halt.

ğŸ“–Definition of time/space-bounded: let T:Nâ†’NT:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NT:Nâ†’N and S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N be functions with T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n. We say MMM is T(n)T(n)T(n) time-bounded, if for every xâˆˆÎ£âˆ—x\in\Sigma^*xâˆˆÎ£âˆ— we have timeM(x)â‰¤T(âˆ£xâˆ£)time_M(x)\le T(|x|)timeMâ€‹(x)â‰¤T(âˆ£xâˆ£). Similarly, MMM is S(n)S(n)S(n) space-bounded, if for every xâˆˆÎ£âˆ—x\in\Sigma^*xâˆˆÎ£âˆ— we have spaceM(x)â‰¤S(âˆ£xâˆ£)space_M(x)\le S(|x|)spaceMâ€‹(x)â‰¤S(âˆ£xâˆ£).

Then define the first complexity classes based on time/space bounds.

ğŸ“–Definition of DTIME,DSPACEDTIME,DSPACEDTIME,DSPACE: DTIME(T(n))DTIME(T(n))DTIME(T(n)) is the class of languages computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded Turing machine and DSPACE(S(n))DSPACE(S(n))DSPACE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space Turing machine.

DDD ä»£è¡¨ deterministic ï¼ˆç¡®å®šï¼‰ã€‚ç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœºæ¯æ¬¡çŠ¶æ€è½¬ç§»åªæœ‰ä¸€ç§ã€‚

NNN ä»£è¡¨ non-deterministic ï¼ˆéç¡®å®šï¼‰ã€‚éç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœºæ¯æ¬¡çŠ¶æ€è½¬ç§»å¯èƒ½æœ‰å¤šç§ï¼Œæœºå™¨éšæœºé€‰æ‹©å…¶ä¸­çš„ä¸€ç§è¿›è¡Œè½¬ç§»ã€‚

Why OOO notation here?

  1. Compressing several tapes symbols to one class by an arbitrary linear factor.

  2. WLOG, one work tape can simulate kkk work tapes by special marking char.

    ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´å¯ä»¥ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªæ ‡è®°å­—ç¬¦æŠŠä¸€ä¸ªå·¥ä½œçº¸å¸¦åˆ†æˆ kkk ä»½ã€‚

ğŸ“–Definition of time/space-constructible: TTT is time-constructible if there is a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded Turing machine computing the function 1nâ†¦1T(n)1^n\mapsto 1^{T(n)}1nâ†¦1T(n). SSS is space-constructible if there is a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) time-bounded Turing machine computing the function 1nâ†¦1S(n)1^n\mapsto 1^{S(n)}1nâ†¦1S(n).

Universal Turing Machines

Universal Turing machine has a fixed amount of work tapes and a fixed tape alphabet.

Set of states QQQ is identified with positive integers from 111 to âˆ£Qâˆ£|Q|âˆ£Qâˆ£.

Î£\SigmaÎ£ and Î“\GammaÎ“ is also identified with positive integers.

Î´\deltaÎ´ can be encoded by its function table.

Given: encoding of a Turing machine MMM with kkk work tapes with an encoding of an input xxx to MMM. (encoding of xxx is concatenation of each char in xxx).

ğŸ¯Theorem 1. For any kâ‰¥1k\ge1kâ‰¥1, there exist a Turing machine UkU_kUkâ€‹ with k+1k+1k+1 work tapes s.t. when given as input an encoding of a Turing machine MMM with kkk work tapes together with an encoding of an input xxx, simulates the computation of MMM on input xxx using time O(timeM(x))O(time_M(x))O(timeMâ€‹(x)) and space O(spaceM(x))O(space_M(x))O(spaceMâ€‹(x)).

â€œSimulatesâ€ here means Uk+1U_{k+1}Uk+1â€‹ provides same output, terminal state as MMM.

Sublogarithmic Space

Usually assume that S(n)â‰¥logâ¡nS(n)\ge\log nS(n)â‰¥logn.

What if S(n)=o(logâ¡n)S(n)=o(\log n)S(n)=o(logn)? In this case Turing machine canâ€™t even be able to describe the position of the input tape head.

O(1)O(1)O(1) space-bounded Turing machine is equivalent to a two-way finite automaton.

To accept non-regular language, the minimal space should be O(logâ¡logâ¡n)O(\log\log n)O(loglogn).

Storage configuration: a state of MMM, position of tape heads, non-black portions of the work tapes. # storage configuration: at most âˆ£Qâˆ£skâˆ£Î“âˆ£s+kâˆ’1=2O(s)|Q|s^k|\Gamma|^{s+k-1}=2^{O(s)}âˆ£Qâˆ£skâˆ£Î“âˆ£s+kâˆ’1=2O(s).

ğŸ¯Theorem 2. Let MMM be a S(n)S(n)S(n) space-bounded Turing machine for a function S(n)=o(logâ¡logâ¡n)S(n)=o(\log\log n)S(n)=o(loglogn). Then MMM is in fact O(1)O(1)O(1) space-bounded.

Proof via contradiction.

Storage configuration is periodic.

MMM will produce at most 22O(s)2^{2^{O(s)}}22O(s) crossing sequences.

Turing Machine Configurations

Configuration è¢«ç¿»è¯‘ä¸ºâ€œæ ¼å±€â€â€¦â€¦æ— åŠ›åæ§½

A configuration of a Turing machine MMM with kkk work tapes:

  1. State of MMM
  2. Positions of k+1k+1k+1 tapes head
  3. Non-blank portions of the work tapes

Observation: If a Turing machine repeats a configuration, it will enter an infinite loop, infinitely repeating the computation taking place between two repeating configurations.

The Space Hierarchy Theorem

Idea: More resources means more can be computed.

ğŸ¯Theorem 3: Let S2(n)â‰¥logâ¡nS_2(n)\ge\log nS2â€‹(n)â‰¥logn be space constructible. If S1(n)=o(S2(n))S_1(n)=o(S_2(n))S1â€‹(n)=o(S2â€‹(n)), then

DSPACE(S1(n))âŠŠDSPACE(S2(n)).DSPACE(S_1(n))\subsetneq DSPACE(S_2(n)).DSPACE(S1â€‹(n))âŠŠDSPACE(S2â€‹(n)).

ä¸­æ–‡ç®€å•è§£é‡Šä¸€ä¸‹ï¼šå›¾çµæœºçš„å¯ç”¨æ¸è¿›å­˜å‚¨ç©ºé—´è¶Šå¤šï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè§£å†³çš„é—®é¢˜ä¹Ÿå°±è¶Šå¤šã€‚

It suffices to construct a O(S2(n))O(S_2(n))O(S2â€‹(n)) space bounded Turing machine MMM s.t. L(M)âˆˆÌ¸DSPACE(S1(n))L(M)\not\in DSPACE(S_1(n))L(M)î€ âˆˆDSPACE(S1â€‹(n)).

Input xxx of length n=âˆ£xâˆ£n=|x|n=âˆ£xâˆ£:

  1. Mark S2(n)S_2(n)S2â€‹(n) cells of work tape using the space constructability of S2S_2S2â€‹. During the remaining computation:
    • Ensuring that computation does not use more than S2(n)S_2(n)S2â€‹(n) additional cells of work tape. This is done by immediately halting (reject).
    • Ensuring that computation does not run for more than 22S2(n)2^{2S_2(n)}22S2â€‹(n) steps, by keeping time with a binary counter on 2S2(n)2S_2(n)2S2â€‹(n) bits. (accept)
  2. Check if the input is on the form x=0i1wx=0^i1wx=0i1w, here www is an encoding of a Turing machine with a single work tape. Otherwise halt by rejecting.
  3. Simulate Mâ€²M'Mâ€² on input xxx using the universal Turing machine U1U_1U1â€‹. If this causes Mâ€²M'Mâ€² to halt, halt and reject if Mâ€²M'Mâ€² accepts. Otherwise accept.

Then analysis MMM and Mâ€²M'Mâ€²â€¦

Tape Reduction and Oblivious Turing Machines

A T(n)T(n)T(n) time-bounded computation of a Turing machine with any number of work tapes can be simulated by a O(T(n)2)O(T(n)^2)O(T(n)2) time-bounded Turing machine with a single work tape. (Simple divide work tape into kkk tracks.)

This is used to prove DTIME(T1(n))âŠŠDTIME(T2(n))DTIME(T_1(n))\subsetneq DTIME(T_2(n))DTIME(T1â€‹(n))âŠŠDTIME(T2â€‹(n)) when T2(n)>nT_2(n)>nT2â€‹(n)>n is time-constructible and (T1(n))2=o(T2(n))(T_1(n))^2=o(T_2(n))(T1â€‹(n))2=o(T2â€‹(n)).

ğŸ“–Definition of oblivious: Let MMM be a Turing Machine. MMM is oblivious if for any nâ‰¥1n\ge1nâ‰¥1 and any input xxx of length n=âˆ£xâˆ£n=|x|n=âˆ£xâˆ£, during computation with input xxx and until MMM halts, the location of all tape heads of MMM is a function of nnn and the number ttt of steps of the computation so far.

It is easy to modify the O(T(n)2)O(T(n)^2)O(T(n)2) to be oblivious by first copying the input to an additional track, and thereafter keeping the input head stationary.

ğŸ¯Theorem 4: Let T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n and suppose MMM is a T(n)T(n)T(n) time-bounded Turing machine with kkk work tapes. Then there exist a O(T(n)logâ¡T(n))O(T(n)\log T(n))O(T(n)logT(n)) time-bounded oblivious Turing machine Mâ€²M'Mâ€² with 222 work tapes s.t. L(M)=L(Mâ€²)L(M)=L(M')L(M)=L(Mâ€²).

Hard proof.

The Time Hierarchy Theorem

ğŸ¯Theorem 5: Let T2(n)â‰¥nT_2(n)\ge nT2â€‹(n)â‰¥n be time constructible. If T1(n)â‰¥nT_1(n)\ge nT1â€‹(n)â‰¥n satisfies T1(n)logâ¡T1(n)=o(T2(n))T_1(n)\log T_1(n)=o(T_2(n))T1â€‹(n)logT1â€‹(n)=o(T2â€‹(n)), then

DTIME(T1(n))âŠŠDTIME(T2(n)).DTIME(T_1(n))\subsetneq DTIME(T_2(n)).DTIME(T1â€‹(n))âŠŠDTIME(T2â€‹(n)).

Proof by tape reduction.

Time and Space Complexity Classes

There are some standard complexity classes given by natural classes of time and space bounds.

L=DSPACE(logâ¡n)P=â‹ƒk>0DTIME(nk)PSPACE=â‹ƒk>0DSPACE(nk)EXP=â‹ƒk>0DTIME(2nk)L=DSPACE(\log n)\\P=\bigcup_{k>0}DTIME(n^k)\\PSPACE=\bigcup_{k>0}DSPACE(n^k)\\EXP=\bigcup_{k>0}DTIME(2^{n^k})L=DSPACE(logn)P=k>0â‹ƒâ€‹DTIME(nk)PSPACE=k>0â‹ƒâ€‹DSPACE(nk)EXP=k>0â‹ƒâ€‹DTIME(2nk)

Trivially, LâŠ†PâŠ†PSPACEâŠ†EXPL\subseteq P\subseteq PSPACE\subseteq EXPLâŠ†PâŠ†PSPACEâŠ†EXP.

A space bounded Turing machine cannot repeat a configuration without entering an infinite loop, thus DSPACE(S(n))âŠ†DTIME(2O(S(n)))DSPACE(S(n))\subseteq DTIME(2^{O(S(n))})DSPACE(S(n))âŠ†DTIME(2O(S(n))) for S(n)>logâ¡nS(n)>\log nS(n)>logn.

Unknown: whether any of the inclusions are strict. But time and space hierarchy theorems give that LâŠŠPSPACEL\subsetneq PSPACELâŠŠPSPACE and PâŠŠEXPP\subsetneq EXPPâŠŠEXP.

LLL means LOGSPACELOGSPACELOGSPACE, PPP denotes PTIMEPTIMEPTIME, EXPEXPEXP denotes EXPTIMEEXPTIMEEXPTIME.

Obviously(???really???), DTIME(T(n))âŠ†DSPACE(T(n))DTIME(T(n))\subseteq DSPACE(T(n))DTIME(T(n))âŠ†DSPACE(T(n)), showing that space is more â€œvaluable thanâ€ time. More precisely, DTIME(T(n))âŠ†DSPACE(T(n)/logâ¡T(n))DTIME(T(n))\subseteq DSPACE(T(n)/\log T(n))DTIME(T(n))âŠ†DSPACE(T(n)/logT(n)) for T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n.

The Padding Technique

Whether LâŠ†PL\subseteq PLâŠ†P and PSPACEâŠ†EXPPSPACE\subseteq EXPPSPACEâŠ†EXP are strict is related.

ğŸ¯Theorem 6: If L=PL=PL=P, then PSPACE=EXPPSPACE=EXPPSPACE=EXP.

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 14 Markov Chains and Random Walks
entry.content:
Lecture notes by Elias Koutsoupias from Oxford

Markov Chains

Definitions

A discrete-time finite Markov chain is a sequence of random variables X=X0,X1,X2,â‹¯X=X_0,X_1,X_2,\cdotsX=X0â€‹,X1â€‹,X2â€‹,â‹¯ taking values in a finite set of states {1,2,â‹¯â€‰,n}\{1,2,\cdots,n\}{1,2,â‹¯,n} s.t. âˆ€tâˆˆN:\forall t\in\mathbb N:âˆ€tâˆˆN:

Prâ¡(Xt+1=jâˆ£Xt=i)=Qi,j,\Pr(X_{t+1}=j|X_t=i)=Q_{i,j},Pr(Xt+1â€‹=jâˆ£Xtâ€‹=i)=Qi,jâ€‹,

where Q=(Qi,j)Q=(Q_{i,j})Q=(Qi,jâ€‹) is an nÃ—nn\times nnÃ—n stochastic transition matrix.

XtX_tXtâ€‹ represents the state of the Markov chain at time ttt and the matrix QQQ encodes the state-to-state transition probabilities. The characteristic property of a Markov chain is that the distribution of XtX_tXtâ€‹ depends only on Xtâˆ’1X_{t-1}Xtâˆ’1â€‹. The conditional probability above is independent of the time ttt.

The ttt-step transition probabilities are given by the power matrix QtQ^tQt, i.e.,

Prâ¡(Xs+t=jâˆ£Xs=i)=Qi,jt,\Pr(X_{s+t}=j|X_s=i)=Q_{i,j}^t,Pr(Xs+tâ€‹=jâˆ£Xsâ€‹=i)=Qi,jtâ€‹,

âˆ€s,tâˆˆN\forall s,t\in\mathbb Nâˆ€s,tâˆˆN. Thus,

Prâ¡(Xt=j)=âˆ‘i=1nQi,jtâ‹…Prâ¡(X0=i).\Pr(X_t=j)=\sum_{i=1}^nQ_{i,j}^t\cdot\Pr(X_0=i).Pr(Xtâ€‹=j)=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Qi,jtâ€‹â‹…Pr(X0â€‹=i).

A Markov chain is completely determined by the distribution of X0X_0X0â€‹ and the transition matrix QQQ.

A Markov chain can be represented as a weighted directed graph whose vertices are the states of the chain and in which there is an edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) of weight Qi,jQ_{i,j}Qi,jâ€‹ whenever Qi,j>0Q_{i,j}\gt0Qi,jâ€‹>0. We define the weight of a path to the product of the weights of the edges along the path, i.e. the probability to take the path. Then the sum of the weights of all length-kkk paths iii to jjj is Qi,jkQ_{i,j}^kQi,jkâ€‹.

The term random walk usually refers to the random process in which a particle moves on a graph, selecting the next node uniformly at random from the adjacent nodes. It is the special case of a Markov chain when for every state iii all probabilities Qi,jQ_{i,j}Qi,jâ€‹ for jâ‰ ij\neq ijî€ =i are equal and Qi,i=0Q_{i,i}=0Qi,iâ€‹=0.

A lazy random walk is similar but Qi,i=1/2Q_{i,i}=1/2Qi,iâ€‹=1/2.

Randomized 2-SAT

Given a 2-CNF formula, either find a satisfying assignment or determine that no such assignment exists.

CNF aka conjunctive normal formï¼Œåˆå–èŒƒå¼ï¼Œå½¢å¦‚ ()\and()\and()

2-CNF å°±æ˜¯ ()\and()\and()\cdots\and()ï¼Œæ‹¬å·å†…é‡Œé¢æ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªå¸ƒå°”å˜é‡çš„æå–ã€‚

DNF aka disjunctive normal formï¼Œæå–èŒƒå¼ï¼Œå½¢å¦‚ ()\or()\or()

2-SAT is solvable in polynomial time (in fact linear time).

There is a polynomial time randomized algorithm for 2-CNF formulas whose analysis is based on a random walk.

Pseudo-code

Randomized 2-SAT(Ï†)(\varphi)(Ï†)

  • Pick a random assignment
  • Repeat 2n22n^22n2 times or until a satisfying assignment is found
    • Pick an unsatisfied clause CCC
    • Pick a literal in CCC uniformly at random, and flip its value
  • Return current assignment if satisfying, else return unsatisfiable

Analysis

If the Ï†\varphiÏ† is not satisfiable then the algorithm returns unsatisfiable. However, if Ï†\varphiÏ† is satisfiable then the algorithm might not find a satisfying assignment. We analyze the probability that the algorithm gives correct answer.

Consider Ï†\varphiÏ† is satisfiable. Let SSS be a particular assignment that satisfies Ï†\varphiÏ†.

Then we bound the probability that algorithm finds SSS. If Ï†\varphiÏ† is not satisfied by an assignment AAA there must be an unsatisfied clause CCC. Observe that one or both literals of CCC must have different truth values under AAA and SSS. Thus if we flip a random literal in CCC then the probability that we increase the agreement between AAA and SSS is either 1/21/21/2 or 111.

Writing AtA_tAtâ€‹ for the assignment after ttt iterations of the main loop and XtX_tXtâ€‹ for the number of variables in which AtA_tAtâ€‹ agrees with SSS, we have

Prâ¡(Xt+1=1âˆ£Xt=0)=1Prâ¡(Xt+1=i+1âˆ£Xt=i)â‰¥1/2,iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯â€‰,nâˆ’1}Prâ¡(Xt+1=iâˆ’1âˆ£Xt=i)â‰¤1/2,iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯â€‰,nâˆ’1}Prâ¡(Xt+1=nâˆ£Xt=n)=1\Pr(X_{t+1}=1|X_t=0)=1\\\Pr(X_{t+1}=i+1|X_t=i)\ge1/2,i\in\{1,\cdots,n-1\}\\\Pr(X_{t+1}=i-1|X_t=i)\le1/2,i\in\{1,\cdots,n-1\}\\\Pr(X_{t+1}=n|X_t=n)=1Pr(Xt+1â€‹=1âˆ£Xtâ€‹=0)=1Pr(Xt+1â€‹=i+1âˆ£Xtâ€‹=i)â‰¥1/2,iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,nâˆ’1}Pr(Xt+1â€‹=iâˆ’1âˆ£Xtâ€‹=i)â‰¤1/2,iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,nâˆ’1}Pr(Xt+1â€‹=nâˆ£Xtâ€‹=n)=1

If we replace inequalities with equations, then XXX becomes a Markov chain on the state space [n][n][n]. The Markov chain of this process is:

  flowchart LR0((0))1((1))2((2))3((...))4((n))0-->|1|11-->|1/2|01-->|1/2|22-->|1/2|12-->|1/2|33-->|1/2|23-->|1/2|44-->|1|4

The chain describes the movement of a particle on a line: it is an example of a one-dimensional random walk with one reflecting and one absorbing barrier.

The expected time until Xt=nX_t=nXtâ€‹=n is an upper bound on the expected number of steps for the 2-SAT algorithm to find SSS.

Let hjh_jhjâ€‹ be the expected time for XXX to first reach nnn starting at jjj. Then we have

hn=0h0=1+h1hj=1+hjâˆ’12+hj+12,jâˆˆ{1,â‹¯â€‰,nâˆ’1}h_n=0\\h_0=1+h_1\\h_j=1+\frac{h_{j-1}}{2}+\frac{h_{j+1}}{2},j\in\{1,\cdots,n-1\}hnâ€‹=0h0â€‹=1+h1â€‹hjâ€‹=1+2hjâˆ’1â€‹â€‹+2hj+1â€‹â€‹,jâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,nâˆ’1}

This is a linear system of equations in n+1n+1n+1 unknowns.

By some deduction, we have hj=hj+1+2j+1h_j=h_{j+1}+2j+1hjâ€‹=hj+1â€‹+2j+1. Combining with hn=0h_n=0hnâ€‹=0, we get that hj=n2âˆ’j2h_j=n^2-j^2hjâ€‹=n2âˆ’j2. Thus hjâ‰¤n2âˆ€jh_j\le n^2\forall jhjâ€‹â‰¤n2âˆ€j.

Let TTT denote the number of steps for the 2-SAT algorithm to find assignment SSS starting from some arbitrary assignment. By Markovâ€™s inequality, we have

Prâ¡(Tâ‰¥2n2)â‰¤E[T]2n2â‰¤n22n2=12\Pr(T\ge2n^2)\le\frac{\mathbb E[T]}{2n^2}\le \frac{n^2}{2n^2}=\frac{1}{2}Pr(Tâ‰¥2n2)â‰¤2n2E[T]â€‹â‰¤2n2n2â€‹=21â€‹

Theorem: If Ï†\varphiÏ† is satisfiable then the 2-SAT algorithm returns a satisfying assignment with probability at least 1/21/21/2. If Ï†\varphiÏ† is unsatisfiable then the 2-SAT algorithm is always correct.

The failure probability can be decreased to 2âˆ’N2^{-N}2âˆ’N by repeating the loop 2Nn22Nn^22Nn2 instead of 2n22n^22n2 times.

Randomized 3-SAT

Extending the randomized algorithm for 2-SAT to 3-SAT.

3-SAT is NP-complete. We can use O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n) exhaustive search to solve it.

Suppose a given 3-CNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ† has a satisfying assignment SSS. Let AtA_tAtâ€‹ be the assignment after ttt steps and let XtX_tXtâ€‹ denote the number of propositional variables in which AtA_tAtâ€‹ agrees with SSS. Similarly,

Prâ¡(Xt+1=j+1âˆ£Xt=j)â‰¥1/3Prâ¡(Xt+1=jâˆ’1âˆ£Xt=j)â‰¤2/3\Pr(X_{t+1}=j+1|X_t=j)\ge1/3\\\Pr(X_{t+1}=j-1|X_t=j)\le2/3Pr(Xt+1â€‹=j+1âˆ£Xtâ€‹=j)â‰¥1/3Pr(Xt+1â€‹=jâˆ’1âˆ£Xtâ€‹=j)â‰¤2/3

Then by replacing â‰¤â‰¥\le\geâ‰¤â‰¥ into ===, we turn the process XXX into Markov chain:

  flowchart LR0((0))1((1))2((2))3((...))4((n))0-->|1|11-->|2/3|01-->|1/3|22-->|2/3|12-->|1/3|33-->|2/3|23-->|1/3|44-->|1|4

The expected time for the resulting chain to reach state nnn is an upper bound for the expected time of the algorithm to find a satisfying valuation.

In this case, there is twice likelihood to move away from nnn as to move towards nnn.

Let hjh_jhjâ€‹ denote expected number of steps to reach nnn when starting from state jjj. Then we have the following system of equations

hn=0hj=2hjâˆ’13+hj+13+1h0=h1+1h_n=0\\h_j=\frac{2h_{j-1}}{3}+\frac{h_{j+1}}{3}+1\\h_0=h_1+1hnâ€‹=0hjâ€‹=32hjâˆ’1â€‹â€‹+3hj+1â€‹â€‹+1h0â€‹=h1â€‹+1

By solving this linear system, we get hj=hj+1+2j+2âˆ’3h_j=h_{j+1}+2^{j+2}-3hjâ€‹=hj+1â€‹+2j+2âˆ’3 for all jjj.

With hn=0h_n=0hnâ€‹=0 this leads to hj=2n+2âˆ’2j+2âˆ’3(nâˆ’j)h_j=2^{n+2}-2^{j+2}-3(n-j)hjâ€‹=2n+2âˆ’2j+2âˆ’3(nâˆ’j).

The above bound shows that the expected number of flips to find SSS is at most O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n). This bound is useless. However, we can improve the performance of this procedure by adapting random restarts into search. A random truth assignment leads to a binomial distribution over the states of the Markov chain XXX centered around the state n/2n/2n/2.

Since Markov chain has a tendency to move towards state 000, after running it for a little while we are better off restarting with a random distribution than continuing to flip literals.

After random restart, by Chernoff bounds, the current assignment differs from SSS is approximately n/2n/2n/2 positions with high probability.

There is an algorithm trying to find a satisfying assignment in N=O((4/3)nn)N=O((4/3)^n\sqrt n)N=O((4/3)nnâ€‹) phases. where each phase starts with a random restart and consists of 3n3n3n literal flips.

Pseudo-code

Randomized 3-SAT(Ï†)(\varphi)(Ï†)

  • Repeat NNN times or until a satisfying assignment is found
    • Pick a random assignment
    • Repeat 3n3n3n times or until a satisfying assignment is found
      • Pick an unsatisfied clause CCC
      • Pick a literal in CCC uniformly at random, and flip its value
  • Return current assignment if satisfying, else return unsatisfiable

Theorem: If Ï†\varphiÏ† is satisfiable then the 3-SAT algorithm returns a satisfying assignment with probability at least 1/21/21/2. If Ï†\varphiÏ† is unsatisfiable then the 2-SAT algorithm is always correct.

Let qjq_jqjâ€‹ be the probability to reach position nnn with 3n3n3n steps starting from position nâˆ’jn-jnâˆ’j. We have

qjâ‰¥C3jj(2/3)j(1/3)2j,q_j\ge C_{3j}^j(2/3)^j(1/3)^{2j},qjâ€‹â‰¥C3jjâ€‹(2/3)j(1/3)2j,

since this is the probability to make exactly 2j2j2j right moves and jjj left moves in the first 3jâ‰¤3n3j\le3n3jâ‰¤3n steps.

By Stirlingâ€™s formula:

2Ï€m(me)mâ‰¤m!â‰¤22Ï€m(me)m,\sqrt{2\pi m}(\frac{m}{e})^m\le m!\le2\sqrt{2\pi m}(\frac{m}{e})^m,2Ï€mâ€‹(emâ€‹)mâ‰¤m!â‰¤22Ï€mâ€‹(emâ€‹)m,

we have

C3jj=(3j)!j!(2j)!â‰¥cj(27/4)j(c=38Ï€).C_{3j}^j=\frac{(3j)!}{j!(2j)!}\\\ge\frac{c}{\sqrt j}(27/4)^j\\(c=\frac{\sqrt3}{8\sqrt\pi}).C3jjâ€‹=j!(2j)!(3j)!â€‹â‰¥jâ€‹câ€‹(27/4)j(c=8Ï€â€‹3â€‹â€‹).

Thus when j>0j\gt0j>0,

qjâ‰¥C3jj(2/3)j(1/3)2jâ‰¥cj(27/4)j(2/3)j(1/3)2jâ‰¥cj12j.q_j\ge C_{3j}^j(2/3)^j(1/3)^{2j}\\\ge \frac{c}{\sqrt j}(27/4)^j(2/3)^j(1/3)^{2j}\\\ge\frac{c}{\sqrt j}\frac{1}{2^j}.qjâ€‹â‰¥C3jjâ€‹(2/3)j(1/3)2jâ‰¥jâ€‹câ€‹(27/4)j(2/3)j(1/3)2jâ‰¥jâ€‹câ€‹2j1â€‹.

The probability of success drops exponentially with the distance jjj between the initial random assignment of the phase and the satisfying truth assignment. But by Chernoff bounds, the probability that this distance is away from n/2n/2n/2 also drops exponentially.

Having established a lower bound for qjq_jqjâ€‹ we now obtain a lower bound for qqq, the probability to reach state nnn with 3n3n3n steps in case the initial state of the random walk is determined by a random assignment. We have

qâ‰¥âˆ‘j=0nPrâ¡(walkÂ startsÂ atÂ nâˆ’j)â‹…qjâ‰¥12n+âˆ‘j=1nCnj(1/2)ncj12jâ‰¥cn(1/2)nâˆ‘j=0nCnj(1/2)j=cn(3/4)n.q\ge\sum_{j=0}^n\Pr(\text{walk starts at }n-j)\cdot q_j\\\ge\frac{1}{2^n}+\sum_{j=1}^nC_n^j(1/2)^n\frac{c}{\sqrt j}\frac{1}{2^j}\\\ge\frac{c}{\sqrt n}(1/2)^n\sum_{j=0}^nC_n^j(1/2)^j\\=\frac{c}{n}(3/4)^n.qâ‰¥j=0âˆ‘nâ€‹Pr(walkÂ startsÂ atÂ nâˆ’j)â‹…qjâ€‹â‰¥2n1â€‹+j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Cnjâ€‹(1/2)njâ€‹câ€‹2j1â€‹â‰¥nâ€‹câ€‹(1/2)nj=0âˆ‘nâ€‹Cnjâ€‹(1/2)j=ncâ€‹(3/4)n.

The number of phases to find a satisfying assignment is a geometric random variable with parameter qqq, so the expected number of phases to find a satisfying assignment is 1/q1/q1/q. Thus the algorithm finds a satisfying assignment with probability at least 1/21/21/2 after N=2/qN=2/qN=2/q phases.

Stationary Distributions

Definition

Let XXX be a Markov chain with transition matrix QQQ. A probability distribution Ï€\piÏ€ on the set of states is called stationary distribution of XXX if

Ï€=Ï€Q.\pi=\pi Q.Ï€=Ï€Q.

Given states i,ji,ji,j of a Markov chain, the hitting time Hi,jH_{i,j}Hi,jâ€‹ is a random variable giving the number of steps to visit state jjj starting from state iii. Formally we have

Hi,j=minâ¡{t>0:Xt=jâˆ£X0=i}.H_{i,j}=\min\{t\gt0:X_t=j|X_0=i\}.Hi,jâ€‹=min{t>0:Xtâ€‹=jâˆ£X0â€‹=i}.

We define hi,j=E[Hi,j]h_{i,j}=\mathbb E[H_{i,j}]hi,jâ€‹=E[Hi,jâ€‹] to be the mean hitting time.

In general hi,jh_{i,j}hi,jâ€‹ may be infinite. Certainly hi,j=âˆh_{i,j}=\inftyhi,jâ€‹=âˆ if jjj is not reachable from iii in the underlying graph, or, if iii can reach a state kkk from which jjj is no longer reachable. We therefore restrict attention to Markov chains whose underlying graph consists of a single strongly connected component. We call such chains irreducible.

We can still have hi,j=âˆh_{i,j}=\inftyhi,jâ€‹=âˆ in an irreducible chain.

Consider Markov chain XXX with set of states {1,2,3,â‹¯â€‰}\{1,2,3,\cdots\}{1,2,3,â‹¯} and transition matrix QQQ, where Qi,i+1=i/(i+1)Q_{i,i+1}=i/(i+1)Qi,i+1â€‹=i/(i+1) and Qi,1=1/(i+1)Q_{i,1}=1/(i+1)Qi,1â€‹=1/(i+1). Starting at state 111, the probability not to have returned to state 111 with ttt steps is

âˆj=1tjj+1=1t+1.\prod_{j=1}^t\frac{j}{j+1}=\frac{1}{t+1}.j=1âˆtâ€‹j+1jâ€‹=t+11â€‹.

Thus we return to state 111 almost surely, but the expected return time is

h1,1=[H1,1]=âˆ‘j=1âˆPrâ¡(H1,1â‰¥j)=âˆ‘j=1âˆ1j+1=âˆh_{1,1}=\mathbb[H_{1,1}]=\sum_{j=1}^\infty\Pr(H_{1,1}\ge j)\\=\sum_{j=1}^\infty\frac{1}{j+1}=\inftyh1,1â€‹=[H1,1â€‹]=j=1âˆ‘âˆâ€‹Pr(H1,1â€‹â‰¥j)=j=1âˆ‘âˆâ€‹j+11â€‹=âˆ

In finite irreducible Markov chain, the mean hitting time between any pair of states is always finite.

Theorem: For any pair of states i,ji,ji,j in a finite irreducible Markov chain, hi,j<âˆh_{i,j}\lt\inftyhi,jâ€‹<âˆ.

Let ddd be the diameter of the underlying graph, let Ïµ>0\epsilon\gt0Ïµ>0 be the smallest positive entry of the transition matrix QQQ. Then for any pair of states i,ji,ji,j, if the chain is started in iii then it visits jjj within ddd steps with probability at least Ïµd\epsilon^dÏµd.

hi,j=E[Hi,j]=âˆ‘t=1âˆPrâ¡(Hi,jâ‰¥t)â‰¤âˆ‘t=1âˆ(1âˆ’Ïµd)âŒŠt/dâŒ‹<âˆ.h_{i,j}=\mathbb E[H_{i,j}]\\=\sum_{t=1}^\infty\Pr(H_{i,j}\ge t)\le\sum_{t=1}^\infty(1-\epsilon^d)^{\lfloor t/d\rfloor}\lt\infty.hi,jâ€‹=E[Hi,jâ€‹]=t=1âˆ‘âˆâ€‹Pr(Hi,jâ€‹â‰¥t)â‰¤t=1âˆ‘âˆâ€‹(1âˆ’Ïµd)âŒŠt/dâŒ‹<âˆ.

A finite irreducible Markov chain has a unique stationary distribution.

Theorem: A finite irreducible Markov chain has a unique stationary distribution Ï€\piÏ€ where Ï€j=1/hj,j\pi_j=1/h_{j,j}Ï€jâ€‹=1/hj,jâ€‹ for each state jjj.

Stationary distribution represents a time average. On average the chain visits state jjj every hj,jh_{j,j}hj,jâ€‹ steps, and thus spends proportion of time Ï€j=1/hj,j\pi_j=1/h_{j,j}Ï€jâ€‹=1/hj,jâ€‹ in state jjj. We expect that the stationary distribution is also a space average, i.e., the distribution of XtX_tXtâ€‹ converges to Ï€\piÏ€ as ttt tends to infinity. However, in general this need not be true.

Definition of period: The period of a state iii in a Markov chain is defined to be gcdâ¡{m>0:Qi,im>0}\gcd\{m\gt0:Q_{i,i}^m\gt0\}gcd{m>0:Qi,imâ€‹>0}. A state is aperiodic if it has period 111. A Markov chain is aperiodic if all states are aperiodic.

A Markov chain is irreducible and aperiodic iff there exists some power of the transition matrix PPP with all entries strictly positive.

Theorem: Consider a finite, irreducible, aperiodic Markov chain with stationary distribution Ï€\piÏ€. Then limâ¡nâ†’âˆQn\lim_{n\rarr\infty}Q^nlimnâ†’âˆâ€‹Qn is the matrix

Qâˆ=[Ï€1Ï€2â‹¯Ï€nÏ€1Ï€2â‹¯Ï€nâ‹¯â‹¯â‹¯â‹¯Ï€1Ï€2â‹¯Ï€n]Q^\infty=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\pi_1&\pi_2&\cdots&\pi_n\\\pi_1&\pi_2&\cdots&\pi_n\\\cdots&\cdots&\cdots&\cdots\\\pi_1&\pi_2&\cdots&\pi_n\\\end{array}\right]Qâˆ=â£â¢â¢â¢â¡â€‹Ï€1â€‹Ï€1â€‹â‹¯Ï€1â€‹â€‹Ï€2â€‹Ï€2â€‹â‹¯Ï€2â€‹â€‹â‹¯â‹¯â‹¯â‹¯â€‹Ï€nâ€‹Ï€nâ€‹â‹¯Ï€nâ€‹â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¥â¤â€‹

If follows that for any initial distribution xxx we have xQbâ†’xQâˆ=Ï€xQ^b\rarr xQ^\infty=\pixQbâ†’xQâˆ=Ï€ as nâ†’âˆn\rarr\inftynâ†’âˆ, i.e., the chain converges to the stationary distribution from any starting point.

Random walks on undirected graphs

Let G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) be a finite, undirected and connected graph. The degree of a vertex vâˆˆVv\in VvâˆˆV is the number d(v)d(v)d(v) of edges incident to vvv. A random walk on GGG is a Markov chain modeling a particle that moves along the edges of GGG and which is equally likely to take any outgoing edge at a given vertex/

Formally a random walk on GGG has set of states is VVV and for each edge {u,v}âˆˆE\{u,v\}\in E{u,v}âˆˆE the probability to transition from uuu to vvv is 1/d(u)1/d(u)1/d(u).

Claim: A random walk on GGG is aperiodic iff GGG is not bipartite.

Theorem: A random walk on a connected graph GGG has a unique stationary distribution Ï€\piÏ€, where

Ï€v=d(v)2E.\pi_v=\frac{d(v)}{2E}.Ï€vâ€‹=2Ed(v)â€‹.

æ‰€æœ‰ç‚¹çš„åº¦æ•°ä¹‹å’Œç­‰äº 2âˆ£Eâˆ£2|E|2âˆ£Eâˆ£.

(Ï€P))u=âˆ‘vâˆˆN(u)d(v)2âˆ£Eâˆ£1d(v)=d(u)2âˆ£Eâˆ£=Ï€uâˆ€uâˆˆV(\pi P))_u=\sum_{v\in N(u)}\frac{d(v)}{2|E|}\frac{1}{d(v)}=\frac{d(u)}{2|E|}=\pi_u\forall u\in V(Ï€P))uâ€‹=vâˆˆN(u)âˆ‘â€‹2âˆ£Eâˆ£d(v)â€‹d(v)1â€‹=2âˆ£Eâˆ£d(u)â€‹=Ï€uâ€‹âˆ€uâˆˆV

Corollary: Let hu,vh_{u,v}hu,vâ€‹ denote the expected number of steps to go from vertex uuu to vertex vvv. Then for any vertex uuu we have

hu,u=2âˆ£Eâˆ£d(u)h_{u,u}=\frac{2|E|}{d(u)}hu,uâ€‹=d(u)2âˆ£Eâˆ£â€‹

Theorem: If u,vu,vu,v are adjacent then hv,u<2âˆ£Eâˆ£h_{v,u}\lt 2|E|hv,uâ€‹<2âˆ£Eâˆ£.

omitted.

Theorem: The cover time of a connected graph GGG with nnn nodes and mmm edges is at most 4nm4nm4nm.

omitted

s-t connectivity

We bound on the cover time of random walks to design an impressively simple space efficient algorithm for the fundamental problem of s-t connectivity. In this problem we are given an undirected graph with nnn nodes, not necessarily connected. We are also given two nodes s,ts,ts,t and we want to find out whether s,ts,ts,t are connected.

Pseudo-code

s-t connectivity(G,s,t)(G,s,t)(G,s,t)

  • start a random walk from sss
  • If ttt is reached in 4n34n^34n3 steps then return reachable else return unreachable

No false positives in the algorithm.

By Markovâ€™s inequality, the algorithm outputs a path from sss to ttt with probability 1/21/21/2.

The algorithm only needs to store a constant number of vertex-addresses at any one time.

If follows that we can decide reach-ability in undirected graph in O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn) space using randomization.

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 13 Nearest Neighbor Search with Different Distance Metrics
entry.content:
Recall

Recall the problem of nearest neighbor search: Randomized ccc-approximate RRR-near neighbor search. Recall that given a set PPP of nnn points in Rd\mathbb R^dRd and parameters R>0,Î´>0R\gt0,\delta\gt0R>0,Î´>0. Also given a distance function dist:RdÃ—Rdâ†’Rdist:\mathbb R^d\times\mathbb R^d\rarr\mathbb Rdist:RdÃ—Rdâ†’R. For a query point qqq, if there is an RRR-near neighbor ppp of qqq (dist(p,q)â‰¤Rdist(p,q)\le Rdist(p,q)â‰¤R), we must report some point pâ€²p'pâ€² that is a cRcRcR-near neighbor of qqq (dist(pâ€²,q)â‰¤cRdist(p',q)\le cRdist(pâ€²,q)â‰¤cR) with probability 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´.

Sensitive Hash Functions. Family of hash functions H\mathcal HH to be (R,cR,P1,P2)(R,cR,P_1,P_2)(R,cR,P1â€‹,P2â€‹)-sensitive for distdistdist if

  1. for all p,qâˆˆRdp,q\in\mathbb R^dp,qâˆˆRd with dist(p,q)â‰¤R:Prâ¡hâˆ¼H[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¥P1dist(p,q)\le R:\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]\ge P_1dist(p,q)â‰¤R:Prhâˆ¼Hâ€‹[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¥P1â€‹.
  2. for all p,qâˆˆRdp,q\in\mathbb R^dp,qâˆˆRd with dist(p,q)â‰¥cR:Prâ¡hâˆ¼H[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¤P2dist(p,q)\ge cR:\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]\le P_2dist(p,q)â‰¥cR:Prhâˆ¼Hâ€‹[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¤P2â€‹.

Solutions. With query time O(L(d+tk))O(L(d+tk))O(L(d+tk)) and space O(nd+Ln)O(nd+Ln)O(nd+Ln), where L=O(nlnâ¡P1/lnâ¡P2)L=O(n^{\ln P_1/\ln P_2})L=O(nlnP1â€‹/lnP2â€‹), ttt is the time to evaluate a hash function from HHH and k=logâ¡P2(1/n)k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)k=logP2â€‹â€‹(1/n).

Hamming Distance. Hash functions for Hamming distance: a uniform hash function hhh in H\mathcal HH chooses a uniform random bit position and returns the corresponding bit as the hash value. H\mathcal HH was (R,cR,1âˆ’R/d,1âˆ’cR/d)(R,cR,1-R/d,1-cR/d)(R,cR,1âˆ’R/d,1âˆ’cR/d)-sensitive and we proved that exponent Ï=lnâ¡P1/lnâ¡P2\rho=\ln P_1/\ln P_2Ï=lnP1â€‹/lnP2â€‹ satisfies Ïâ‰¤1/c\rho\le 1/cÏâ‰¤1/c.

Other Distance Measures

l1-distance

For 2 points p,qâˆˆRdp,q\in\mathbb R^dp,qâˆˆRd, we have â„“1\ell_1â„“1â€‹-distance âˆ‘i=1dâˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£\sum_{i=1}^d|p_i-q_i|âˆ‘i=1dâ€‹âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£. Given the radius RRR and approximation factor ccc, we can design a sensitive family of hash functions as follows: For a radius www to be determined, consider the family:

H={hi,o(x)=âŒŠxiâˆ’owâŒ‹âˆ£iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯â€‰,d},oâˆˆ[0,w)}\mathcal H=\left\{h_{i,o}(x)=\left\lfloor\frac{x_i-o}{w}\right\rfloor| i\in\{1,\cdots,d\},o\in[0,w)\right\}H={hi,oâ€‹(x)=âŒŠwxiâ€‹âˆ’oâ€‹âŒ‹âˆ£iâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,d},oâˆˆ[0,w)}

To get a hash function from H\mathcal HH, a coordinate iii and offset ooo are drawn uniformly and independently.

The hash value of the point xxx is âŒŠ(xiâˆ’o)/wâŒ‹\lfloor(x_i-o)/w\rfloorâŒŠ(xiâ€‹âˆ’o)/wâŒ‹.

Consider iii and hi,oh_{i,o}hi,oâ€‹ has been chosen, but ooo is still uniform random in [0,w)[0,w)[0,w). For points p,qp,qp,q, hi,o(p)h_{i,o}(p)hi,oâ€‹(p) and hi,o(q)h_{i,o}(q)hi,oâ€‹(q) equal precisely when âŒŠ(piâˆ’o)/wâŒ‹=âŒŠ(qiâˆ’o)/wâŒ‹\lfloor(p_i-o)/w\rfloor=\lfloor(q_i-o)/w\rfloorâŒŠ(piâ€‹âˆ’o)/wâŒ‹=âŒŠ(qiâ€‹âˆ’o)/wâŒ‹. The expression âŒŠ(xâˆ’oi)/wâŒ‹\lfloor(x-o_i)/w\rfloorâŒŠ(xâˆ’oiâ€‹)/wâŒ‹ changes value precisely at points x=oi+jwx=o_i+jwx=oiâ€‹+jw for jâˆˆZj\in\mathbb ZjâˆˆZ.

Whatâ€™s the probability that a point of the form oi+jwo_i+jwoiâ€‹+jw lies between pip_ipiâ€‹ and qiq_iqiâ€‹?

  • If âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£â‰¥w|p_i-q_i|\ge wâˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£â‰¥w, then this happens with probability 111.
  • Otherwise, the probability is âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£/w|p_i-q_i|/wâˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£/w.

Thus we have Prâ¡[âŒŠ(piâˆ’oi)/wâŒ‹=âŒŠ(qiâˆ’oi)/wâŒ‹]=maxâ¡{0,1âˆ’âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£/w}\Pr[\lfloor(p_i-o_i)/w\rfloor=\lfloor(q_i-o_i)/w\rfloor]=\max\{0,1-|p_i-q_i|/w\}Pr[âŒŠ(piâ€‹âˆ’oiâ€‹)/wâŒ‹=âŒŠ(qiâ€‹âˆ’oiâ€‹)/wâŒ‹]=max{0,1âˆ’âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£/w}.

Since iii is chosen uniformly, we get

Prâ¡hâˆ¼H[h(p)=h(q)]=âˆ‘i=1d1dmaxâ¡{0,1âˆ’âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£/w}.\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]=\sum_{i=1}^d\frac{1}{d}\max\{0,1-|p_i-q_i|/w\}.hâˆ¼HPrâ€‹[h(p)=h(q)]=i=1âˆ‘dâ€‹d1â€‹max{0,1âˆ’âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£/w}.

Let us first assume dist(p,q)â‰¤Rdist(p,q)\le Rdist(p,q)â‰¤R. If we choose wâ‰¥Rw\ge Rwâ‰¥R, then the above simplifies to

Prâ¡hâˆ¼H[h(p)=h(q)]=âˆ‘i=1d1dâ‹…(1âˆ’âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£/w)=1âˆ’âˆ‘i=1dâˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£dw=1âˆ’dist(p,q)dwâ‰¥1âˆ’Rdw\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]=\sum_{i=1}^d\frac1d\cdot(1-|p_i-q_i|/w)\\=1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^d|p_i-q_i|}{dw}=1-\frac{dist(p,q)}{dw}\ge1-\frac{R}{dw}hâˆ¼HPrâ€‹[h(p)=h(q)]=i=1âˆ‘dâ€‹d1â€‹â‹…(1âˆ’âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£/w)=1âˆ’dwâˆ‘i=1dâ€‹âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£â€‹=1âˆ’dwdist(p,q)â€‹â‰¥1âˆ’dwRâ€‹

On the other hand, assume dist(p,q)>cRdist(p,q)\gt cRdist(p,q)>cR and assume we choose wâ‰¥cRw\ge cRwâ‰¥cR. Then we get:

Prâ¡hâˆ¼H[h(p)=h(q)]=âˆ‘i=1d1dmaxâ¡{0,1âˆ’âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£/w}=âˆ‘i=1d1dâ‹…(1âˆ’minâ¡{w,âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£}w)=1âˆ’âˆ‘i=1dminâ¡{w,âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£}dw.\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]=\sum_{i=1}^d\frac{1}{d}\max\{0,1-|p_i-q_i|/w\}\\=\sum_{i=1}^d\frac{1}{d}\cdot(1-\frac{\min\{w,|p_i-q_i|\}}{w})\\=1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^d\min\{w,|p_i-q_i|\}}{dw}.hâˆ¼HPrâ€‹[h(p)=h(q)]=i=1âˆ‘dâ€‹d1â€‹max{0,1âˆ’âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£/w}=i=1âˆ‘dâ€‹d1â€‹â‹…(1âˆ’wmin{w,âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£}â€‹)=1âˆ’dwâˆ‘i=1dâ€‹min{w,âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£}â€‹.

Assume first that âˆ€i:âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£â‰¤w\forall i:|p_i-q_i|\le wâˆ€i:âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£â‰¤w. Then the above equals

1âˆ’âˆ‘i=1dâˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£dw=1âˆ’dist(p,q)dwâ‰¤1âˆ’cRdw1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^d|p_i-q_i|}{dw}=1-\frac{dist(p,q)}{dw}\le1-\frac{cR}{dw}1âˆ’dwâˆ‘i=1dâ€‹âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£â€‹=1âˆ’dwdist(p,q)â€‹â‰¤1âˆ’dwcRâ€‹

On the other hand, assume âˆƒi:âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£>w\exist i:|p_i-q_i|\gt wâˆƒi:âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£>w, then the above has upper bound:

Prâ¡hâˆ¼H[h(p)=h(q)]=1âˆ’âˆ‘i=1dminâ¡{w,âˆ£piâˆ’qiâˆ£}dwâ‰¤1âˆ’wdwâ‰¤1âˆ’cRdw\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]=1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^d\min\{w,|p_i-q_i|\}}{dw}\\\le 1-\frac{w}{dw}\le1-\frac{cR}{dw}hâˆ¼HPrâ€‹[h(p)=h(q)]=1âˆ’dwâˆ‘i=1dâ€‹min{w,âˆ£piâ€‹âˆ’qiâ€‹âˆ£}â€‹â‰¤1âˆ’dwwâ€‹â‰¤1âˆ’dwcRâ€‹

Thus H\mathcal HH is (R,cR.1âˆ’R/(dw),1âˆ’cR/(dw))(R,cR.1-R/(dw),1-cR/(dw))(R,cR.1âˆ’R/(dw),1âˆ’cR/(dw))-sensitive if we choose wâ‰¥cRw\ge cRwâ‰¥cR. This results in L=O(nÏ)L=O(n^\rho)L=O(nÏ) for

Ï=lnâ¡P1lnâ¡P2=lnâ¡(1âˆ’R/(dw))lnâ¡(1âˆ’cR/(dw))â‰¤lnâ¡(1âˆ’R/(dw))lnâ¡(1âˆ’R/(dw))c=1c\rho=\frac{\ln P_1}{\ln P_2}=\frac{\ln(1-R/(dw))}{\ln(1-cR/(dw))}\le\frac{\ln(1-R/(dw))}{\ln(1-R/(dw))^c}=\frac{1}{c}Ï=lnP2â€‹lnP1â€‹â€‹=ln(1âˆ’cR/(dw))ln(1âˆ’R/(dw))â€‹â‰¤ln(1âˆ’R/(dw))cln(1âˆ’R/(dw))â€‹=c1â€‹

We also have k=logâ¡P2(1/n)=lnâ¡(1/n)lnâ¡(1âˆ’cR/(dw))k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)=\frac{\ln(1/n)}{\ln(1-cR/(dw))}k=logP2â€‹â€‹(1/n)=ln(1âˆ’cR/(dw))ln(1/n)â€‹. By 1âˆ’xâ‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’x)1-x\le\exp(-x)1âˆ’xâ‰¤exp(âˆ’x), we have

k=logâ¡P2(1/n)=lnâ¡(1/n)lnâ¡(1âˆ’cR/(dw))â‰¤lnâ¡(1/n)âˆ’cR/(dw)=dwlnâ¡n/(cR).k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)=\frac{\ln(1/n)}{\ln(1-cR/(dw))}\le\frac{\ln(1/n)}{-cR/(dw)}=dw\ln n/(cR).k=logP2â€‹â€‹(1/n)=ln(1âˆ’cR/(dw))ln(1/n)â€‹â‰¤âˆ’cR/(dw)ln(1/n)â€‹=dwlnn/(cR).

Set Similarity Search

Consider the data consists of sets rather than points.

Input consist of nnn sets S1,â‹¯â€‰,SnS_1,\cdots,S_nS1â€‹,â‹¯,Snâ€‹, all subsets of a universe UUU.

Measure for set similarity: Jaccard coefficient

J(A,B)=âˆ£Aâˆ©Bâˆ£âˆ£AâˆªBâˆ£J(A,B)=\frac{|A\cap B|}{|A\cup B|}J(A,B)=âˆ£AâˆªBâˆ£âˆ£Aâˆ©Bâˆ£â€‹

The coefficient lies between 000 and 111 with J(A,B)=1J(A,B)=1J(A,B)=1 when AAA and BBB are identical and J(A,B)=0J(A,B)=0J(A,B)=0 when AAA and BBB are disjoint.

The Nearest Neighbor Queries on sets: Given a set CCC, find the set SiS_iSiâ€‹ in the data that is most similar to CCC.

Goal: Use the LSH. For LSH we need to distance metric. Which is the opposite of Jaccard coefficient.

distJ(A,B)=1âˆ’J(A,B)dist_J(A,B)=1-J(A,B)distJâ€‹(A,B)=1âˆ’J(A,B)

How to define LSH function for this distance metric? Use min-wise independent families of hash function. A family of hash functions H:Uâ†’R\mathcal H:U\rarr\mathbb RH:Uâ†’R is min-wise independent if âˆ€xâˆˆU,SâŠ‚U\forall x\in U,S\subset Uâˆ€xâˆˆU,SâŠ‚U with xâˆ‰Sx\notin Sxâˆˆ/S, it holds that

The above definition means that in any set, each element has exactly the same probability of receiving the smallest hash value. We assume that any hâˆˆHh\in\mathcal HhâˆˆH returns distinct values for all xâˆˆUx\in UxâˆˆU i.e. h(x)â‰ h(y)h(x)\neq h(y)h(x)î€ =h(y) for any xâ‰ yx\neq yxî€ =y and any hâˆˆHh\in\mathcal HhâˆˆH.

Assume that we have a min-wise independent family of hash functions H\mathcal HH and define from it a new family of hash function GHâŠ‚2Uâ†’U:\mathcal G_\mathcal H\subset 2^U\rarr U:GHâ€‹âŠ‚2Uâ†’U:

Constructing Min-Wise Independent Families

All of above assumed that we had a min-wise independent family of hash functions H\mathcal HH. Unfortunately it can be proved that such families of hash functions are impossible to construct using a small random seed. However, we can still find efficient families that are only approximately min-wise independent.

It suffices to get reasonable nearest neighbor search structures.

We say that a family of hash function H\mathcal HH is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-approximate min-wise independent, if for any xâˆˆUx\in UxâˆˆU and any SâŠ‚US\subset USâŠ‚U with xâˆ‰Sx\notin Sxâˆˆ/S, we have

Prâ¡hâˆ¼H[h(x)<minâ¡yâˆˆSh(y)]âˆˆ1Â±Ïµâˆ£Sâˆ£+1\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(x)\lt\min_{y\in S}h(y)]\in\frac{1\pm\epsilon}{|S|+1}hâˆ¼HPrâ€‹[h(x)<yâˆˆSminâ€‹h(y)]âˆˆâˆ£Sâˆ£+11Â±Ïµâ€‹

Indyk showed that any O(lnâ¡(1/Ïµ))O(\ln(1/\epsilon))O(ln(1/Ïµ))-wise independent family of hash functions is also Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-approximate min-wise independent. A classic example of kkk-wise independent family of hash function is the following for any prime p>Up\gt Up>U:

H={hakâˆ’1,â‹¯â€‰,a0(x)=âˆ‘i=1kâˆ’1aixiÂ modÂ pâˆ£a0,â‹¯â€‰,akâˆ’1âˆˆ[p]}.\mathcal H=\left\{ h_{a_{k-1},\cdots,a_0}(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}a_ix^i\text{ mod }p|a_0,\cdots,a_{k-1}\in[p] \right\}.H={hakâˆ’1â€‹,â‹¯,a0â€‹â€‹(x)=i=1âˆ‘kâˆ’1â€‹aiâ€‹xiÂ modÂ pâˆ£a0â€‹,â‹¯,akâˆ’1â€‹âˆˆ[p]}.

Someone proved that the simple tabulation hash function is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-approximate min-wise independent with Ïµ=O(lgâ¡2n/n1/c)\epsilon=O(\lg^2n/n^{1/c})Ïµ=O(lg2n/n1/c) where ccc is number of tables used for the hash function and nnn is the cardinality of the set SSS. So the quality depends on the set cardinalities and therefore simple tabulation hashing works best for rather large sets.

How the approximation affects the sensitivity of the hash function:

Prâ¡ghâˆ¼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]=âˆ‘xâˆˆAâˆ©BPrâ¡hâˆ¼H[Ex]â‰¤âˆ‘xâˆˆAâˆ©B1+Ïµâˆ£(AâˆªB)â•²{x}âˆ£+1=(1+Ïµ)â‹…âˆ£Aâˆ©Bâˆ£âˆ£AâˆªBâˆ£=(1+Ïµ)â‹…J(A,B).\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]=\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[E_x]\\\le\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\frac{1+\epsilon}{|(A\cup B)\diagdown\{x\}|+1}\\=(1+\epsilon)\cdot\frac{|A\cap B|}{|A\cup B|}\\=(1+\epsilon)\cdot J(A,B).ghâ€‹âˆ¼GHâ€‹Prâ€‹[ghâ€‹(A)=ghâ€‹(B)]=xâˆˆAâˆ©Bâˆ‘â€‹hâˆ¼HPrâ€‹[Exâ€‹]â‰¤xâˆˆAâˆ©Bâˆ‘â€‹âˆ£(AâˆªB)â•²{x}âˆ£+11+Ïµâ€‹=(1+Ïµ)â‹…âˆ£AâˆªBâˆ£âˆ£Aâˆ©Bâˆ£â€‹=(1+Ïµ)â‹…J(A,B).

Therefore, for distJ(A,B)>cRdist_J(A,B)\gt cRdistJâ€‹(A,B)>cR, we have

Prâ¡ghâˆ¼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]â‰¤(1+Ïµ)J(A,B)â‰¤(1+Ïµ)(1âˆ’distJ(A,B))â‰¤(1+Ïµ)(1âˆ’cR).\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]\\\le(1+\epsilon)J(A,B)\\\le(1+\epsilon)(1-dist_J(A,B))\\\le(1+\epsilon)(1-cR).ghâ€‹âˆ¼GHâ€‹Prâ€‹[ghâ€‹(A)=ghâ€‹(B)]â‰¤(1+Ïµ)J(A,B)â‰¤(1+Ïµ)(1âˆ’distJâ€‹(A,B))â‰¤(1+Ïµ)(1âˆ’cR).

Analogously, we also have

Prâ¡ghâˆ¼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]=âˆ‘xâˆˆAâˆ©BPrâ¡hâˆ¼H[Ex]â‰¥âˆ‘xâˆˆAâˆ©B1âˆ’Ïµâˆ£(AâˆªB)â•²{x}âˆ£+1=(1âˆ’Ïµ)â‹…âˆ£Aâˆ©Bâˆ£âˆ£AâˆªBâˆ£=(1âˆ’Ïµ)â‹…J(A,B).\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]=\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[E_x]\\\ge\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\frac{1-\epsilon}{|(A\cup B)\diagdown\{x\}|+1}\\=(1-\epsilon)\cdot\frac{|A\cap B|}{|A\cup B|}\\=(1-\epsilon)\cdot J(A,B).ghâ€‹âˆ¼GHâ€‹Prâ€‹[ghâ€‹(A)=ghâ€‹(B)]=xâˆˆAâˆ©Bâˆ‘â€‹hâˆ¼HPrâ€‹[Exâ€‹]â‰¥xâˆˆAâˆ©Bâˆ‘â€‹âˆ£(AâˆªB)â•²{x}âˆ£+11âˆ’Ïµâ€‹=(1âˆ’Ïµ)â‹…âˆ£AâˆªBâˆ£âˆ£Aâˆ©Bâˆ£â€‹=(1âˆ’Ïµ)â‹…J(A,B).

This implies that for distJ(A,B)â‰¤Rdist_J(A,B)\le RdistJâ€‹(A,B)â‰¤R, we have

Prâ¡ghâˆ¼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]â‰¥(1âˆ’Ïµ)J(A,B)=(1âˆ’Ïµ)(1âˆ’distJ(A,B))â‰¥(1âˆ’Ïµ)(1âˆ’R).\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]\\\ge(1-\epsilon)J(A,B)\\=(1-\epsilon)(1-dist_J(A,B))\\\ge(1-\epsilon)(1-R).ghâ€‹âˆ¼GHâ€‹Prâ€‹[ghâ€‹(A)=ghâ€‹(B)]â‰¥(1âˆ’Ïµ)J(A,B)=(1âˆ’Ïµ)(1âˆ’distJâ€‹(A,B))â‰¥(1âˆ’Ïµ)(1âˆ’R).

Thus GH\mathcal G_\mathcal HGHâ€‹ is (R,cR,(1âˆ’R)(1âˆ’Ïµ),(1âˆ’cR)(1+Ïµ))(R,cR,(1-R)(1-\epsilon),(1-cR)(1+\epsilon))(R,cR,(1âˆ’R)(1âˆ’Ïµ),(1âˆ’cR)(1+Ïµ))-sensitive.

For upper bound on Prâ¡[h(p)=h(q)]\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]Pr[h(p)=h(q)]:

Prâ¡[h(p)=h(q)]=âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆ12Ï€expâ¡(âˆ’x2/2)â‹…maxâ¡{0,1âˆ’(dist(p,q)/w)âˆ£xâˆ£}dxâ‰¤âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆ12Ï€expâ¡(âˆ’x2/2)â‹…(1âˆ’(dist(p,q)/w)âˆ£xâˆ£)dx+2â‹…âˆ«w/dist(p,q)âˆ12Ï€expâ¡(âˆ’x2/2)â‹…(dist(p,q)/w)xdx=â‹¯â‹¯=1âˆ’2/Ï€(dist(p,q)/w)(1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2).\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)\cdot\max\{0,1-(dist(p,q)/w)|x|\}dx\\\le\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)\cdot(1-(dist(p,q)/w)|x|)dx\\+2\cdot\int_{w/dist(p,q)}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)\cdot(dist(p,q)/w)xdx\\=\cdots\cdots\\=1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(dist(p,q)/w)(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2}).Pr[h(p)=h(q)]=âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆâ€‹2Ï€â€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’x2/2)â‹…max{0,1âˆ’(dist(p,q)/w)âˆ£xâˆ£}dxâ‰¤âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆâ€‹2Ï€â€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’x2/2)â‹…(1âˆ’(dist(p,q)/w)âˆ£xâˆ£)dx+2â‹…âˆ«w/dist(p,q)âˆâ€‹2Ï€â€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’x2/2)â‹…(dist(p,q)/w)xdx=â‹¯â‹¯=1âˆ’2/Ï€â€‹(dist(p,q)/w)(1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2).

Assume wâ‰«dist(p,q)w\gg dist(p,q)wâ‰«dist(p,q) and ignore (1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2)(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})(1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2). Under this simplification, we get for p,qp,qp,q with dist(p,q)>cRdist(p,q)\gt cRdist(p,q)>cR that Prâ¡[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¤1âˆ’2/Ï€(cR/w)\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]\le1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(cR/w)Pr[h(p)=h(q)]â‰¤1âˆ’2/Ï€â€‹(cR/w).

The we bound Ï\rhoÏ in L=O(nÏ)L=O(n^\rho)L=O(nÏ):

Ï=lnâ¡P1/lnâ¡P2=lnâ¡(1âˆ’2/Ï€(R/w))/lnâ¡(1âˆ’2/Ï€(cR/w))â‰¤lnâ¡(1âˆ’2/Ï€(R/w))/lnâ¡(1âˆ’2/Ï€(R/w))c=1/c\rho=\ln P_1/\ln P_2=\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(R/w))/\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(cR/w))\\\le\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(R/w))/\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(R/w))^c=1/cÏ=lnP1â€‹/lnP2â€‹=ln(1âˆ’2/Ï€â€‹(R/w))/ln(1âˆ’2/Ï€â€‹(cR/w))â‰¤ln(1âˆ’2/Ï€â€‹(R/w))/ln(1âˆ’2/Ï€â€‹(R/w))c=1/c

If we donâ€™t ignore (1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2)(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})(1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2), then

Ïâ‰¤1c(1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2)\rho\le\frac{1}{c(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})}Ïâ‰¤c(1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2)1â€‹

By choosing www, we need to estimate on the largest value of dist(p,q)dist(p,q)dist(p,q).

Then we bound kkk.

P2=1âˆ’2/Ï€(cR/w)P_2=1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(cR/w)P2â€‹=1âˆ’2/Ï€â€‹(cR/w), ignoring (1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2)(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})(1âˆ’eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2).

Be have k=logâ¡P2(1/n)=lnâ¡(1/n)/lnâ¡P2=lnâ¡(1/n)/lnâ¡(1âˆ’2/Ï€(cR/w))k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)=\ln(1/n)/\ln P_2=\ln(1/n)/\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(cR/w))k=logP2â€‹â€‹(1/n)=ln(1/n)/lnP2â€‹=ln(1/n)/ln(1âˆ’2/Ï€â€‹(cR/w)).

kâ‰¤lnâ¡(1/n)/lnâ¡(eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2)=lnâ¡n/(2/Ï€cR/w)=O(wlnâ¡n/(cR))k\le\ln(1/n)/\ln(e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})=\ln n/(\sqrt{2/\pi}cR/w)=O(w\ln n/(cR))kâ‰¤ln(1/n)/ln(eâˆ’(w/dist(p,q))2/2)=lnn/(2/Ï€â€‹cR/w)=O(wlnn/(cR))

This means we should be careful not to choose www too large.
